entry.title: Tracing an ancient MƒÅori jade trade route in New Zealand
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Te Rua Mason believes finding pounamu is much like finding love. Despite the spitting rain and biting wind, Te Rua, his son Henare and I are picking our way along the pebbled mouth of the Arahura River outside Hokitika township. The steel-grey Tasman Sea crashes and foams against the shore nearby, hurling salty spray into the air. Sky-wheeling seagulls bicker and caw.
The weather might be dreary but Te Rua, my guide and founder of Te Rua and Sons Pounamu Trail tours, says it‚Äôs a good day to search for pounamu, a type of jade found exclusively on the west coast of New Zealand‚Äôs South Island. Too much sunlight can wash everything in an indiscernible glare ‚Äî rain helps the stone‚Äôs natural green stand out among the lim‚Ä¶

entry.title: Flags raised in Doha as leaders gather for UN social development summit
entry.summary: Against a quiet morning sky, the flags of the United Nations and the State of Qatar rose together in Doha on Sunday, ahead of the Second World Summit for Social Development.

entry.title: Take part in a master-led healing retreat in the Maldives
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
My body is melting into a puddle of gold. In reality, I‚Äôm lying on the floor in a timber-clad room suspended over a sparkling Indian Ocean lagoon. Both sound far-fetched, but I‚Äôm at a master-led healing retreat in the Maldives, and scenarios like this have become my new normal.
I‚Äôve travelled to The Ritz-Carlton Maldives, Fari Islands to spend four days with Susy Markoe Schieffelin, an LA-based sound healer, kundalini yoga teacher and reiki master, who‚Äôs in residence at the hotel as part of its Masters of Crafts programme.
Over a lunch of spicy tuna poke bowls, looking out across a circular infinity pool, Susy explains the powerful healing qualities of sound. ‚ÄúAs soothing frequencies created by the bowls wash ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Is this the best way to see the Seychelles?
entry.summary:
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Perfect palms arcing over white, fine-grain sand; smooth, sparkling granite boulders rising along the rainforest-clad coastline; and crystalline waters as far as the eye can see ‚Äî Seychelles rightly lives up to its name as one of the world‚Äôs most idyllic escapes. An archipelago made up of 115 islands, the Indian Ocean nation located off the eastern coast of Africa has long lured travellers thanks to its superlative natural beauty and enticing mix of Creole, French and English heritage.
Uninhabited until 1770, when the French established a settlement here, and independent since 1976, Seychelles is one of the youngest nations in Africa ‚Äî but, thanks to a small population and a focus on luxury tourism and fishing, it‚Äô‚Ä¶

entry.title: Paganism is on the rise‚Äîhere‚Äôs where to discover its traditions
entry.summary:
The Ivana Kupala festival, in Kyiv, Ukraine, is part of an ancient pagan tradition believed to cleanse sins and bring good health. TikTok‚Äîspecifically #witchtok‚Äîis fueling interest in paganism. Here‚Äôs how to immerse yourself in full moon rituals, spellcasting, and more.
Interest in Paganism and its rituals‚Äîcrystals and tarot cards, astrology, and herbal magic‚Äîhas brought pagan religion from the fringes back to the center of pop culture, or at least to the top of your TikTok feed.
In ancient times, Celts traveled windy moors to worship the horned god, Cernunnos. Egyptians crossed deserts to invoke the protection of Isis and Osiris. Druids journeyed to a forest clearing to perform rituals under the moon. But over time, such gods and goddesses faded into myth; the rituals of this‚Ä¶

entry.title: Who were the Cathars?
entry.summary:
Early 13th-century Europe saw a rise in dissident Christian communities, including the Cathars and the Waldenses, in several regions of Europe. The dissident movements questioned central elements of Catholic doctrine: the validity of the sacraments and the Church‚Äôs message on salvation of the soul. They believed the Church and its members had moved away from the Christian ideal and they demanded a return to evangelical poverty. Before the Inquisition, the Catholic Church addressed doctrinal dissent by organizing public debates with the dissenters in an attempt to bring them back to the ‚Äútrue faith.‚Äù
Diego de Acebes, bishop of the Castilian diocese of Burgode Osma, who saw firsthand how Catharism was taking hold, warned the Catholic prelates of southern France about the need to change ‚Ä¶

entry.title: To experience the real D.C., visit these 7 neighborhoods
entry.summary:
Virginia Ali and her husband Ben Ali opened¬†Ben‚Äôs Chili Bowl¬†in Washington, D.C.‚Äôs U Street neighborhood in 1958 when she was 24. The diner serving homemade chili and its signature half-smokes (half pork, half beef sausages) became a fixture on Black Broadway, the epicenter of Black society and the Civil Rights Movement in the nation‚Äôs capital from the 1920s through the 1950s. ‚ÄúWhen we opened Ben‚Äôs, we wanted it to be a welcoming place for everybody, and it became a gathering place,‚Äù says Ali, 92.¬†
Just two miles away from the District‚Äôs iconic Washington Monument on the National Mall, Ben‚Äôs Chili Bowl is an attraction of its own‚Äîa local neighborhood gem and a D.C. time capsule with stories of presidents and historical figures, too. Ben‚Äôs is just one of the many restaurants, shops, th‚Ä¶

entry.title: November‚Äôs supermoon will be the biggest and brightest of 2025
entry.summary:
A supermoon lights up Longquan Mountain in Chengdu, China, on August 19, 2024. This November‚Äôs full moon will appear even closer to Earth, glowing larger and brighter in the autumn sky. The glow of the moon will even cast faint shadows on the ground, a rare effect visible only during the most intense supermoons. Here‚Äôs the best time to see and photograph it.
On November 4, the moon will put on its brightest and largest show of the year. It‚Äôs the second in a series of three consecutive supermoons closing out 2025.
Sometimes called the ‚Äúbeaver moon,‚Äù this full moon‚Äôs name‚Äîtraditionally used by various Indigenous peoples of North America‚Äîmarks the season when beavers build their winter lodges and when trappers once set out before rivers froze over.
The size difference might ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What's missing at the new Grand Egyptian Museum?
entry.summary:
You won't find the western Luxor Obelisk at the Grand Egyptian Museum‚ÄîEgypt's highly anticipated new museum filled with treasures of antiquity. The obelisk was gifted from Egypt to France, where it remains on the Place de la Concorde, Paris. The hotly anticipated new museum boasts some of the greatest treasures of antiquity. But there are some notable exceptions.
After more than two decades and with plenty of hiccups along the way, the Grand Egyptian Museum‚Äîcolloquially, the ‚ÄúGEM‚Äù‚Äîfinally officially opens in Cairo on November 1.
The halls of the museum are filled to the brim with priceless artifacts like the colossus statue of Ramesses II, Khufu‚Äôs ancient royal boats, and 5,000 treasures from Tutankhamun‚Äôs tomb‚Äîwhich will be displayed together for the first time since the tomb‚Ä¶

entry.title: What caused Strasbourg‚Äôs dancing plague of 1518?
entry.summary:
Around 400 people danced for days without rest in Strasbourg, Alsace during the dancing plague of 1518. Over the course of about one month, some of those affected died of heart attack, stroke, or exhaustion. Mass hysteria? Ergot poisoning? Or just despair? Here‚Äôs why what started as one woman‚Äôs dance spiraled into one of history‚Äôs strangest outbreaks.
The¬†Black Death¬†rightfully stands top of mind among historic plagues. Yet there was an odder malady that also swept across medieval and Renaissance Europe: the dancing plague, also known as choreomania.
It saw large groups of people dancing for prolonged periods in an erratic, frenzied manner, seemingly unable to control their movements or stop moving to the point of collapse, with some dying as a result. Groups ballooned into th‚Ä¶

entry.title: What if aliens exist‚Äîbut they‚Äôre just hiding from us?
entry.summary:
Could there be a technologically advanced extraterrestrial society hiding in NGC 604, a star-forming region of the Triangulum Galaxy captured here by the James Webb Space Telescope? Astronomers have long wondered why we haven't yet encountered alien civilizations even though humanity is young and our universe is ancient‚Äîa conundrum known as the Fermi Paradox. The Dark Forest theory is just one explanation for our lack of encounters with extraterrestrial intelligence.
The Dark Forest theory is one proposed solution to the famed Fermi Paradox, which has bewitched astronomers for more than half a century. To put it concisely, the paradox asks if the cosmos is nearly 14 billion years old, then where are all the interstellar societies? Why haven‚Äôt they popped over to say hello? Myriad s‚Ä¶

entry.title: A British tradition you can‚Äôt miss‚Äî16 of the UK‚Äôs best Sunday roasts
entry.summary:
Chef Luke Payne's Sunday menu at The Pack Horse is popular with walkers, day-trippers and locals within this Peak District hotspot. In the UK the roast dinner is often the highlight of Sunday, especially when it‚Äôs served up in a cosy pub, with local ingredients and a touch of contemporary flair.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK)
In Britain, the Sunday roast is sacrosanct. Gathering together around a beautifully cooked joint of meat, with lashings of gravy, vegetables and billowing Yorkshire puddings, is, for many, the weekend‚Äôs social highlight. And where better to do to this than the pub? Not only do you avoid the washing-up but, centuries after the French dubbed Brits les rosbifs, you get to enjoy the roast at its most modern. In recent decade‚Ä¶

entry.title: Was Nanotyrannus real?
entry.summary: Nanotyrannus was long thought to be the very prey it's shown attacking in the illustration above, a young Tyrannosaurus rex. New evidence suggests it was a different class of dinosaur.  After decades of fierce debate, researchers say fossils once thought to be juvenile T. rex actually belong to a separate, sleeker species of tyrannosaur. One of paleontology‚Äôs most polarizing problems is a teenage Tyrannosaurus rex with an identity crisis, and two scientists say they‚Äôve solved it. In 1942, researchers from the Cleveland Museum of Natural History found the skull of a small theropod in Montana‚Äôs Hell Creek Formation. After scientists classified it as the new species Nanotyrannus lancensis in 1988, the skull sparked four decades of fierce debate: Do ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Lyon's bouchons offer a masterclass in traditional French cuisine
entry.summary: Les Fines Gueules is a much-loved, traditional bouchon run by Jo√´l Salzi, who trained under the legendary Lyonnais chef Paul Bocuse. The city's traditional restaurants, known as bouchons, are an essential part of its identity and a must-visit for authentic local cuisine. Here are seven of the best to try This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK). With rustic wooden furnishings, cosy bistro atmospheres and hearty Lyonnaise¬†cuisine, bouchons have become a symbol of the French city once best known for its chef-led fine-dining scene. Found in the city‚Äôs older quarters, notably concentrated in the arty area of La Croix-Rousse and central Presqu‚Äô√éle, sandwiched between the Rh√¥ne and Sa√¥ne rivers, bouchons serve typical local cuisine. entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: The American Trends Panel survey methodology Overview Data in this report comes from Wave 180 of the American Trends Panel (ATP), Pew Research Center‚Äôs nationally representative panel of randomly selected U.S. adults. The survey was conducted from Sept. 22 to 28, 2025. A total of 3,445 panelists responded out of 3,926 who were sampled, for [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. How well the Republican and Democratic parties represent Americans‚Äô interests
entry.summary: About four-in-ten U.S. adults (42%) say the Republican Party represents the interests of people like them very or somewhat well. A similar share (40%) say this about the Democratic Party. But majorities say the Republican Party (56%) and Democratic Party (58%) do not represent the interests of people like them. Combining these measures: While most [‚Ä¶] The post 4. How well the Republican and Democratic parties represent Americans‚Äô interests appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. What Americans want and expect from party leaders
entry.summary: Wide majorities of Americans say it is important that both Republican and Democratic elected officials are knowledgeable and admit when they are wrong. Smaller majorities say it is very important that elected officials in both parties be willing to make compromises with the other party and treat their counterparts with respect. And while most Republicans [‚Ä¶] The post 3. What Americans want and expect from party leaders appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. How Americans see the parties on key issues
entry.summary: All in all, Americans don‚Äôt see many good ideas from either political party. But when it comes to specific issues, the Republican Party holds advantages on crime and immigration, while the Democratic Party holds advantages on policies related to race, health care, abortion and the environment. In contrast to a few years ago, neither party [‚Ä¶] The post 2. How Americans see the parties on key issues appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. How Americans feel about the Republican and Democratic parties
entry.summary: Americans largely have negative feelings toward both political parties, while positive sentiments are far less common. Three-quarters of U.S. adults say the Democratic Party makes them feel frustrated, while a smaller majority (64%) says the same of the Republican Party. Roughly half of Americans also say the Democratic Party (50%) and the Republican Party (49%) [‚Ä¶] The post 1. How Americans feel about the Republican and Democratic parties appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: A Year Ahead of the Midterms, Americans‚Äô Dim Views of Both Parties
entry.summary: Democrats‚Äô frustration with their own party is up sharply, as many say it hasn‚Äôt pushed back hard enough against Trump and the GOP. In contrast, 40% of Republicans say they are frustrated with their party. The post A Year Ahead of the Midterms, Americans‚Äô Dim Views of Both Parties appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: America once made daylight saving time permanent. Here‚Äôs what went wrong.
entry.summary:
Horologist Lawrie Taprell adjusts the clock atop the North Sydney Post Office in Australia in 1989. Twice a year, clockkeepers like Taprell fine-tune public timepieces to match daylight saving shifts‚Äîsomething the U.S. once tried to make permanent. In 1974, the U.S. tried staying on daylight saving time all year. The result was darker mornings and public panic.
Love it or hate it, daylight saving time (DST) is one of the world‚Äôs most persistent experiments in tinkering with the sun. Roughly one-third of countries worldwide still practice it, but not without controversy.
In the United States, the federal government first standardized the twice-yearly clock change in 1966. Today, people in almost all U.S. states‚Äîwith the exceptions being Hawaii and most of Arizona‚Äî‚Äúsprings forwa‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why York, England, may be the most haunted city in the world
entry.summary:
York reports a large number of ghost sightings, giving it a reputation as being one of the most haunted cities in Europe. From Roman ruins to candlelit alleyways, this walled city invites travelers to explore the chilling stories that linger where history and the supernatural meet.
Walking through the streets of York, England, feels a bit like traveling back in time. In one afternoon, you can walk among Roman ruins, check out the relics of Viking settlements, and stroll cobbled lanes with crooked medieval buildings. History comes alive in its Gothic cathedrals, Norman castle ruins, and cozy medieval pubs still serving up lagers and whiskeys today.
But what brings much of the visitors to York‚Äîparticularly in the fall‚Äîis its large number of ghost sightings, giving it the reputat‚Ä¶

entry.title: The comeback of California‚Äôs gray wolves just took a tragic turn
entry.summary:
For the first time in over a century, California wildlife officials have taken the drastic measure of legally killing four gray wolves after tensions with local ranchers reached a crisis point.
Earlier this month, the California Department of Fish and Wildlife captured and euthanized a breeding pair after months of complaints from ranchers over numerous livestock kills in a remote region of the Sierra Nevada mountain range known as Sierra Valley. The ultimate goal, according to the department, is to completely remove a seven-member pack called Beyem Seyo, one of 10 packs roaming the state. Two other Beyem Seyo wolves were also killed, and the agency plans to capture and relocate the remaining members to a wildlife sanctuary.
This particular pack has killed at least 87 cattle over‚Ä¶

entry.title: Putting people at the heart of cities, key to improving urban life
entry.summary: The heartbeat of modern urban life is increasingly digital ‚Äì from traffic sensors and early warning systems, to participatory planning platforms and geospatial data ‚Äì technology is changing how cities are designed, managed, and experienced.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòNormalising‚Äô Taliban rule would betray Afghan women, warns UN expert
entry.summary: Governments moving to restore ties with the Taliban risk legitimising oppression and deepening Afghanistan‚Äôs crisis, an independent UN human rights expert cautioned on Thursday, calling for a principled approach that defends the rights of women and girls.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Hurricane Melissa leaves thousands displaced across the Caribbean
entry.summary: Hurricane Melissa has left a trail of devastation after crossing Jamaica, Cuba and the Bahamas, with severe effects also felt in Haiti, the Dominican Republic and parts of Central America, the UN aid coordination office (UNOCHA) reported on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Ukraine energy targeted, nuclear test warning, rights violations in Nicaragua
entry.summary: Russian armed forces conducted another large-scale combined attack across Ukraine in the early hours of Thursday, reportedly targeting critical energy infrastructure, said the UN Human Rights Monitoring Mission for Ukraine.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN Envoy hails Colombia‚Äôs peace process as global model, calls for more funding
entry.summary: The newly appointed Head of the UN Verification Mission in Colombia, Miroslav Jenƒça, has praised the country‚Äôs peace process as ‚Äúa global model,‚Äù while urging greater financial support to strengthen the Mission‚Äôs work.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòRepeated bouts of violence‚Äô put Syria rebuilding at risk: Independent rights investigator
entry.summary: Incidents of mass killings and torture in post-Assad Syria are tempering early optimism about the transitional government‚Äôs ability to put an end to entrenched cycles of violence, the head of the UN-mandated independent investigative body on Syria said on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòBlood on the sand. Blood on the hands‚Äô: UN decries world‚Äôs failure as Sudan‚Äôs El Fasher falls
entry.summary: El Fasher has ‚Äúdescended into an even darker hell,‚Äù senior UN officials warned on Thursday, as the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia seized control of the North Darfur capital after a 500-day siege, forcing tens of thousands to flee on foot amid reports of mass executions, rape and starvation.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Security Council LIVE: Ambassadors meet in emergency session on Sudan
entry.summary: Reports of mass atrocities in and around the newly-captured city of El Fasher in Darfur mark a new low in Sudan's brutal civil war and the Security Council is meeting in emergency session on Thursday morning in New York to address the rapidly deteriorating situation. Civilians are facing starvation and mass displacement as the UN continues providing lifesaving aid throughout the country. Hospitals, schools and IDP camps are under attack, with entire neighborhoods have emptied as families flee the RSF militia. Follow our in-depth live coverage; UN News app users can go here.

entry.title: This Colorado town inspired Disneyland‚Äôs Main Street
entry.summary:
Fort Collins, Colorado, was part of the inspiration for Disneyland's "Main Street, U.S.A." Walt Disney‚Äôs vision of an idyllic ‚ÄúMain Street, U.S.A.‚Äù found a muse in the brick-lined charm of this community that is still ranked among the best places to live in the U.S.
When Walt Disney commissioned Harper Goff to help design Disneyland‚Äôs Main Street, Goff didn‚Äôt have to look far for inspiration. He found it in the brick facades and towers of his childhood hometown, Fort Collins, Colorado, with the buildings‚Äô late Victorian era architectural details making their way into his 1951 sketches for Walt Disney. Goff poured his nostalgia for the simpler days of his childhood into every detail of Disneyland, ensuring that each child who visited could feel the same magic.
Fort Collins stil‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why America was so obsessed with Victorian ‚Äòghost photos‚Äô
entry.summary:
In 1862, jewelry engraver and amateur photographer William H. Mumler was developing a self-portrait in his Boston studio when a ghostly image began to surface. Just below his own image in the photo appeared a young woman in a flowing dress, her features blurred by a ghostly halo.
Mumler showed the picture to his friend, possibly as a joke, and mentioned the woman looked like his deceased cousin. Soon it was being passed through Boston society. It didn‚Äôt take long for the local Spiritualist community to learn of the miraculous photo. The news was blasted to their followers via fringe religious journals: spirits had finally been captured on film.
In fact, the woman who appeared next to Mumler was likely Hannah Frances Green, who worked nearby as a photographer and spirit medium‚Ä¶

entry.title: The science of why some spaces feel haunted‚Äîeven when they're not
entry.summary:
Devoid of students and sound, this empty schoolhouse disorients the brain‚Äôs internal mapping system, turning familiar architecture into a landscape of uncertainty. Scientists say such environments reveal how light, space, and silence can trick the senses into sensing danger where none exists. From looping hallways to echoing stairwells, eerie architecture taps into ancient survival instincts‚Äîand exposes how our brains map spaces to protect us from harm.
We often think of homes and hotels as safe, predictable spaces. Yet step into a corridor that stretches farther than your eyes can focus, and your pulse quickens before you even know why.
Scientists say these sensations aren‚Äôt superstition but the brain misreading its surroundings. Experts reveal how architecture‚Äîthrough walls,‚Ä¶

entry.title: Caught on the RattleCam: unexpected snake behavior
entry.summary:
Two eastern garter snakes are shown. Scientists are finding that snakes exhibit more social behaviors than previously thought. For a long time, scientists didn‚Äôt think snakes needed each other. New research proves that wrong. 
Picture an animal that huddles up with others when stressed, babysits its young, hangs out around relatives, and gathers in big groups every year.¬†
Did you imagine a rattlesnake?
For a long time, scientists didn‚Äôt think snakes could fit this description.
‚ÄúThere were two big myths out there,‚Äù said Noam Miller,¬†who studies animal social cognition at Wilfrid Laurier University. One is that snakes largely just operated on reflex. The other is that snakes don‚Äôt gather in general, since people tend to only come across one snake at a time. ‚ÄúSo t‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to become a cowboy for the day in Scottsdale Arizona
entry.summary:
Since being bestowed the nickname the ‚ÄòWest‚Äôs most Western town‚Äô in the 1940s, Scottsdale in Arizona has become better known for its high-end resorts, spas and golf courses. But peel back the shiny top-layer of this cactus-studded city and you'll soon discover Western roots that run deep into the surrounding Sonoran Desert‚Äôs rocky terrain. The cowboy spirit is evident throughout Old Town Scottsdale, in its lively saloons and Western-wear boutiques, as well as surrounding ranches and museums that showcase Scottsdale‚Äôs pre- and post-frontier past. From exploring sun-drenched landscapes on horseback to learning to triple-step in a Stetson, here‚Äôs how to embrace the cowboy lifestyle in Scottsdale.
Channel your inner John Wayne at the aptly named Arizona Cowboy College, a family-owned wo‚Ä¶

entry.title: The chupacabra‚Äîhow evolution made a mythical monster
entry.summary:
The chupacabra incites fear and fascination, but scientists say the creature is likely a coyote with mange, like the one pictured here. Scientists say a common wildlife disease may be behind the chupacabra legend.
The chupacabra was first reported in Puerto Rico in the mid-1990s. Since then, tales of the mysterious canine-like monster that sucks the blood of livestock have incited fear‚Äîand fascination‚Äîacross Mexico, the U.S. Southwest, and even China.
But scientists say they can explain the stories with the help of evolutionary theory.
Reports of people spotting the flesh-and-blood chupacabras as recently as 2023 make the mythical creature eminently more accessible for study than, say, the Loch Ness monster or Bigfoot.
In almost all these cases, the monsters have tur‚Ä¶

entry.title: The German eccentric who remade America's forests
entry.summary:
A portrait of Carl Alwin Schenck, the forstmeister whose work at the Biltmore Estate and the Pisgah National Forest, transformed the American landscape. A Gilded Age baron invited Carl Alwin Schenck to manage his forest at the Biltmore Estate. The decision changed America's landscape.
On a spring day in 1945, Christoph Rhoeneck perched at the edge of his family‚Äôs balcony. From the top floor of the brown, wood-clad house, in the middle of the southwest German mountain town of Lindenfels, he watched American tanks rolling up the valley below.¬†
Rhoeneck, at the time around five years old, watched the United States Army knock down fences and drive over his neighbors‚Äô gardens, convoying along the village‚Äôs medieval road to the town center.¬†
Now 85 years old, he remembers think‚Ä¶

entry.title: ‚ÄòGlobal perspective‚Äô key to moving humanity forward in space
entry.summary: Space exploration and the development of space technologies are ‚Äúendeavours that require a global perspective,‚Äù which forces nations to work collaboratively according to Professor Brian Cox, the world-renowned astrophysicist who has been appointed UN Champion for Space.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN chief condemns Gaza killings, urges full respect for ceasefire
entry.summary: The UN Secretary-General has strongly condemned the killing of civilians, including children, in Israeli airstrikes across Gaza overnight into Wednesday, calling for all parties to uphold their commitments to the fragile ceasefire

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Myanmar at a crossroads: A choice between impunity and justice
entry.summary: Myanmar stands at a crossroads between impunity and humanitarian crisis, as escalating military airstrikes, widespread civilian casualties and mounting evidence of war crimes continue to devastate the country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN nuclear watchdog highlights Iran, Syria and Ukraine as key global tests
entry.summary: Mounting nuclear risks ‚Äì from Ukraine‚Äôs war-torn power plants to Iran‚Äôs unresolved safeguards, and renewed inspection efforts in Syria ‚Äì are testing the global non-proliferation regime like never before, the UN‚Äôs nuclear watchdog warned on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: South Sudan at risk of return to war, UN investigators warn
entry.summary: South Sudan faces a renewed slide into full-scale conflict unless urgent international action is taken, the UN-appointed independent investigative body examining human rights there warned on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Hurricane Melissa: Devastation in Jamaica at levels ‚Äònever been seen before‚Äô
entry.summary: As Hurricane Melissa moved north of Jamaica on Wednesday, the head of the UN team there said that preliminary damage assessments from the category 5 storm showed a level of devastation ‚Äúnever seen before‚Äù on the Caribbean island.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Towards a fairer world: Leaders gather in Doha to renew social pact
entry.summary: What does it mean to build a society where everyone truly belongs? In a world increasingly shaped by digital divides, demographic shifts and climate disruption, the promise of ‚Äòsocial development for all‚Äô feels urgent, if elusive.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Amid shifting alliances, General Assembly demands end to US embargo on Cuba
entry.summary: The UN General Assembly on Wednesday has ‚Äì for the 33rd consecutive year ‚Äì adopted a resolution calling for an end to the decades-long United States embargo against Cuba.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: ‚ÄòYawning gap‚Äô remains between climate adaptation funds and funding pledges
entry.summary: Developing countries are receiving less than 10 per cent of the money they need to adapt to a world increasingly vulnerable to extreme weather ‚Äì putting lives, livelihoods and entire economies at risk, the UN revealed on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Reported massacre at hospital in Sudan‚Äôs El Fasher leaves 460 dead
entry.summary: Horrific stories of mass-atrocities committed by the RSF militia continue to emerge, along with the tens of thousands of civilians who have fled the North Darfur city of El Fasher in Sudan.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: See the world's cities in a new light with these urban adventures
entry.summary:
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Why join a standard walking tour when there are plenty of novel ways to experience a city, and plenty of ways to indulge a niche interest? Visitors can get uncover New York‚Äôs musical history by diving into its punk scene; learn about the Cold War by driving a Trabant through Berlin; and get a unique perspective of Rio by paragliding above it.
The City of Lights shone brighter than ever last summer with its hosting of the Olympics ‚Äî however, it also has a dark periphery that relatively few tourists seek out. The Petite Ceinture was a railway line with its origins in the mid-19th century. Abandoned since the 1980s, large sections have now been converted into official parks where you can wander among urban foxes and‚Ä¶

entry.title: At this English nature retreat you can birdwatch from bed
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
There‚Äôs never a bad time to visit Elmley Nature Reserve. In the cooler months, murmurations of starlings cloud crisp winter skies while tens of thousands of waders fill rain-fed pools. The beginnings of spring signal the swooping of lapwings and the boxing of hares, while summer lets loose a burst of butterflies and bees. Autumn is peak season for nocturnal birds, with migratory short-eared owls adding to the roster of barn owls, little owls and their long-eared cousins. And you‚Äôll find all of this perhaps where you‚Äôd least expect: the briny marshlands on the southern end of the Isle of Sheppey on the Kent coast. It‚Äôs a clanking industrial heartland, jutting into the North Sea just 40 miles east of London ‚Äî framed by py‚Ä¶

entry.title: They mummified a human with ancient tools. It got messy.
entry.summary: The mummy of King Tutankhamun In an excerpt from his new book Dinner with King Tut, Sam Kean explores a weird and wild '90s experiment to replicate ancient mummification techniques. Excerpted from¬†Dinner with King Tut: How Rogue Archaeologists Are Re-creating the Sights, Sounds, Smells, and Tastes of Lost Civilizations by Sam Kean. Copyright ¬© 2025. Available from Little, Brown and Company, an imprint of Hachette Book Group, Inc. Cultures throughout history have mummified their dead, and a handful still do today, but Egyptian mummies remain the most iconic. Unfortunately, the Egyptians wrote down virtually nothing about their embalming process. This leaves experimental archaeology as one of the few avenues available for understanding mummification, and several ‚Ä¶

entry.title: In winter, Tasmania channels a surprisingly Nordic vibe
entry.summary:
The best time of year to see the southern lights in Tasmania is from May through September. Like Scandinavia, this remote island has built a culture around remoteness, creativity, slow living, and a deep respect for nature.
They may sit on opposite ends of the planet, one skirting the Arctic Circle, the other floating above Antarctica, but Tasmania and Scandinavia share more than just latitude extremes. In winter, this southern island channels a distinctly Nordic spirit: quiet, creative, and deeply connected to the natural world.
The parallels start with the landscape: glacial lakes, pine forests, wild coastlines. But they run deeper. Like Scandinavia, Tasmania has built a quiet culture around remoteness, creativity, and a deep respect for nature. Winter here isn‚Äôt something t‚Ä¶

entry.title: This is what happens to your brain during menopause
entry.summary:
During menopause, women can experience forgetfulness, brain fog, and other cognitive symptoms. Over the years, studies have found that the end of menstruation comes with brain changes including shrinking brain volume and reduced blood flow. Researchers are delving into structural changes in the brain during the midlife transition.
Soon after she rounded 50, Susan Shaw noticed that things began slipping through her brain‚Äîwhere she parked her car, who she needed to call, even the birthday of her best friend. An avid multitasker at work, suddenly the smallest disruptions threw her off. In the five years since, the problem has worsened.¬†
‚ÄúMy brain works differently now than it used to,‚Äù Shaw says. She compensates by creating elaborate to-do lists and asking coworkers not to interr‚Ä¶

entry.title: Avocados and monarch butterflies are on a collision course
entry.summary:
After their long journey south, monarch butterflies gather by the millions in a high-elevation fir forest of El Rosario Sanctuary, part of the Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve in Michoac√°n, Mexico. Climate change and illegal deforestation for avocado production are threatening monarch butterfly ecosystems.
The flapping wings of millions of monarch butterflies at the¬†Monarch Butterfly Biosphere Reserve¬†in Michoac√°n, Mexico, create a fluttering sound that Alfonso Alonso describes as ‚Äúmagical.‚Äù¬†
The butterflies migrate from the northern United States and southern Canada each year just in time for D√≠a de los Muertos on November 1 and 2, when celebrations in many parts of Mexico honor deceased ancestors.¬†
The serendipitous timing may have led to the belief that a monar‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 night sky events to see in November
entry.summary:
A super ‚Äúbeaver moon‚Äù rises behind Monte Prena in Italy‚Äôs Apennine Mountains in November 2024. This year‚Äôs ‚Äúbeaver moon‚Äù‚Äîthe largest full moon of 2025‚Äîkicks off a dazzling month of celestial events, from meteor showers to bright planets lighting up the night sky. The month brings a spectacular lineup of celestial sights‚Äîincluding a rare chance to see Mercury without a telescope and a "micro" new moon.
November kicks off with Mercury making a brilliant evening appearance, then continues with not one, but three meteor showers. The largest full moon of the year rises early in the month, while a later ‚Äúmicro‚Äù new moon offers ideal darkness for harder-to-spot constellations like Orion and Taurus.
Here are 10 celestial events to watch for in November‚Äîand when to look up to catch the‚Ä¶

entry.title: World enters ‚Äònew era‚Äô of climate action ‚Äì but progress must accelerate
entry.summary: While urging countries to accelerate action, UN Climate Change Executive Secretary Simon Stiell struck an optimistic tone on Tuesday following the release of a new report on updated national climate commitments.

entry.title: Gaza: Humanitarian response scaled up amid faltering ceasefire
entry.summary: Aid teams in Gaza are racing to meet urgent needs with tens of thousands still displaced, sheltering in damaged buildings and makeshift sites, while reports of renewed fighting between Israeli forces and Hamas threaten to derail the ceasefire.

entry.summary: As Hurricane Melissa makes landfall in Jamaica as a category 5 storm, agencies continue mobilising supplies to support affected communities, with one senior official on the island telling UN News that Government-led preparations have been nothing short of ‚Äúextraordinary‚Äù.

entry.summary: The chair of an independent commission investigating alleged human rights abuses in the Occupied Palestinian Territory, told a General Assembly committee on Tuesday that Israel has committed ‚Äúfour genocidal acts‚Äù in Gaza, while leaders had ‚Äúincited the commission of genocide.‚Äù

entry.title: ‚ÄòHorrific‚Äô violence as thousands flee Sudan's El Fasher
entry.summary: After 500 days of siege, the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia have reportedly taken control of the key Sudanese city of El-Fasher in Darfur, triggering widespread fear among families, and forcing thousands of civilians to flee.

entry.title: 10 must-see sights in South Africa that most travelers miss
entry.summary:
A group of dolphins creates a network of air bubbles to trap sardines before launching an attack. The African sardine run is when millions of sardines lay their eggs in the cold waters of the Agulhas shoal and then move north along the eastern coast of South Africa. From visiting ancient rock art to sipping wine while on safari, here are the best things to see outside of the most touristed hot spots.
From ancient rock art and epic mountain trails to spicy food scenes and safaris without the crowds, South Africa overflows with sights and activities for tourists. Yet, despite the country being nearly twice the size of Texas, just two destinations dominate tourists‚Äô agenda: the coastal city of Cape Town and the famous Kruger National Park. They‚Äôre undeniable highlights, but tourists a‚Ä¶

entry.title: Top 10 things to know about the Day of the Dead
entry.summary:
Day of the Dead, or D√≠a de los Muertos, is not a Mexican version of Halloween.
Though related, the two annual events differ greatly in traditions and tone. While Halloween embraces terror and mischief on the last night of October, Day of the Dead festivities unfold over the first two days of November in an explosion of color and life-affirming joy.
Sure, the theme is death, but the point of Day of the Dead is to honor the dead by demonstrating love and respect for deceased family members. In towns and cities throughout Mexico, revelers don funky makeup and costumes, hold parades and parties, sing and dance, and make offerings to lost loved ones. What is Day of the Dead?Dia de los Muertos (Day of the Dead) is a celebration of life and death that originated in Mexico. It is no‚Ä¶

entry.title: Scientists reveal the secret of toads that can turn neon yellow
entry.summary:
As the first monsoon rains in India and southeast Asia begin to swell each year, one type of toad experiences an almost literal glow up. A temporary, hormone-induced wardrobe change transforms male Asian common toads (Duttaphrynus melanostictus) from chocolate pudding brown to lemon yellow in a matter of minutes.¬†¬†
While the females‚Äô skin remains brown, males undergo a color palette makeover to get ready for a lightning round of speed dating. Scientists have long known that the color change coincided with a frenzied, annual two-day breeding event, but they only recently confirmed the specific role it plays.¬†
To investigate, researchers from Sch√∂nbrunn Zoo in Vienna 3D printed toads ‚Äî some brown, some yellow ‚Äî and placed them amid real toads gathering to mate. They found that the ‚Ä¶

entry.title: The essential guide to visiting Cairo
entry.summary:
Khan Al-Khalili on Al-Muizz Street is Cairo‚Äôs most famous souk (market), and has been trading rugs, lamps, gold, and jewelry for 600 years. The Pyramids of Giza, medieval markets, and the legendary Nile are just a few highlights of Egypt‚Äôs energetic capital. Here‚Äôs our guide to where to stay, what to eat, and what to know before you visit Cairo.
Fueled by sugar and caffeine, Cairo is a late-night city, and the energy in both its ancient heart and wealthy ‚ÄòNew‚Äô Cairo is boundless. A city with layers of history; the top drawcards are its most ancient: the Nile River and the Pyramids of Giza, which have towered over this frenetic megalopolis for millennia. And documented stories of Egypt‚Äôs empires and eras are on display in a collection of museums spearheaded by the new¬†Grand Egyptian‚Ä¶

entry.title: What destroyed Napoleon‚Äôs army?
entry.summary: Researchers recently found evidence that some of the soldiers who died during Napoleon's retreat from Moscow may have suffered from relapsing fever, caused by the bacteria species Borrelia recurrentis, and paratyphoid fever, caused by a strain of Salmonella. A new genetic analysis of teeth from a mass grave in Lithuania reveals hidden illnesses that plagued the French emperor's soldiers during their disastrous 1812 retreat. As French general and ruler Napoleon Bonaparte returned from a disastrous attempt to conquer Russia in 1812, his army lost tens of thousands of men‚Äîmany of them conscripted by force‚Äîto a fatal combination of extreme cold, exhaustion, starvation and disease. Based on reports from the time, the main diseases thought to have caused ‚Ä¶

entry.title: What makes Appalachian ghost stories so scary?
entry.summary:
TikTok may have led you to believe that Appalachia is populated by an inexhaustible supply of boogers, haints, witches, cryptids. But folklorists say most of the social media videos reveal a fundamental misreading of the region's ghost stories. Very little of the chatter on social media takes up the real lore that makes the region so rich in spooky storytelling.
In the early winter months of 1897, a woman named Mary J. Heaster found herself in regular prayer. Her daughter, Elva Zona Heaster Shue, had just died that January. Only recently married, Zona (as she was known) was a young woman, and her ‚Äúdeath by heart disease‚Äù‚Äîas the county coroner had determined‚Äîweighed heavily on Mary. Had the coroner gotten the cause of death wrong? Mary prayed that her daughter would return to guide ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why hurricanes are getting more powerful‚Äîmore quickly
entry.summary:
As oceans grow warmer, they‚Äôre creating conditions that allow hurricanes to undergo rapid intensification‚Äîwhen a hurricane‚Äôs wind speed increases by 35 mph or more within 24 hours. Hurricane Melissa is the latest examples of this phenomenon.
Hurricane Melissa grew from a tropical storm to a powerful Category 5‚Äî90mph and in the span of 48 hours‚Äîand forecasters predict the storm could cause catastrophic flash flooding, life-threatening landslides, and extremely strong winds across the Caribbean.¬†Hurricane Melissa is set to make landfall in Jamaica early Tuesday as a Category 5 storm, making it the¬†strongest hurricane¬†to hit the island since record keeping began in 1851.
These types of explosive jumps have become more common in recent years, with devastating consequences.¬†

entry.title: See Brazil's outdoors through its greatest natural wonders
entry.summary:
Otherworldly Len√ß√≥is Maranhenses National Park is known for its flooded sands. Brazilian landscapes are known for their drama, with thundering waterfalls, rippling sand dunes and even a Grand Canyon all lying within the country‚Äôs borders.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Home to both the world‚Äôs largest rainforest and mightiest waterfall ‚Äî the Amazon and Iguazu Falls, respectively ‚Äî Brazil is a place of superlatives when it comes to natural wonders, from flooded sand dunes and soaring mountains to archipelagos covered with thick forest.
Brazil‚Äôs vast ecosystems range from tropical wetlands to dry scrublands, plunging canyons to soaring plateaus ‚Äî and between them, they make a home for an incredible 15‚Äì20% of all the plant and animal speci‚Ä¶

entry.title: Children at risk as winter looms amid renewed strikes in Ukraine
entry.summary: Airstrikes and ongoing conflict in Ukraine are leaving civilians ‚Äì including thousands of children ‚Äì without homes, power, water and basic services, as humanitarians warn the approaching winter is heightening the risks for communities along the frontlines.

entry.summary: Drones operated by Russian forces have repeatedly attacked Ukrainian civilians, causing deaths, injuries and large-scale destruction, independent¬†UN human rights investigators said on Monday.

entry.title: Desperate need for water and food continues as Gaza families head north
entry.summary: More than 470,000 movements by civilians heading north inside the Gaza Strip have been recorded since the ceasefire began, said the UN aid coordination office (OCHA) on Monday.

entry.summary: Grave atrocities, including summary executions are reportedly being carried out in the Darfuri regional capital of El Fasher by the Rapid Support Forces (RSF) militia, according to the UN human rights office (OHCHR).

entry.title: An inside guide to √âvora, Portugal‚Äôs soulful university city
entry.summary:
√âvora, 83 miles east of Lisbon, is a small, medieval-walled city with a grand sense of history. The seat of the Portuguese royal family in the 15th¬†and 16th¬†centuries, its littered with historic sites, from Roman to the remains of palaces. Now, it‚Äôs gearing up to step into the spotlight as a European Capital of Culture in 2027, with exhibitions, residencies and performances in the works. But even with this buzz, at heart it remains a low-key, laidback place.
Begin your exploration at the city‚Äôs masterpiece, the Cathedral of √âvora, whose 12th-century towers dominate the skyline. This brooding building is a mix of gothic and romanesque styles, best experienced by climbing to its roof for views across terracotta-topped neighbouring buildings and sunlit plains.
Steps away is the ‚Ä¶

entry.title: I've dined in Tuscany for over 20 years‚Äîthis is where to eat in autumn
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Although Tuscany is often associated with balmy summer days and the incessant cacophony of cicadas, it‚Äôs in the colder months that its food truly sings. As temperatures drop in October, there‚Äôs a sense of respite after the long, languid months of searing heat. Autumn is a season of hard work, when everything Tuscany‚Äôs fertile lands have to offer is harvested and transformed into produce celebrated the world over‚Äîruby-red wines, thick, acid-green new olive oil, plump porcini mushrooms, and musky white truffles. In the mountains, chestnuts fall and are roasted over open flames, their sweet flesh kissed with smoke. Contrary to the meat-heavy image of Tuscan cooking, vegetables, beans, and pulses are central, earning locals‚Ä¶

entry.title: Which is the best island in southeast Asia for you?
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Any Southeast Asian adventure, whether a shorter trip or a cross-country odyssey, will likely take in some of the region‚Äôs 25,000-plus islands. You‚Äôll find plenty of coral-sand bays, seaside bars and swaying palms no matter where you go, but there‚Äôs far more to see beyond the beaches. Indonesia and the Philippines are entire island nations built on millennia of history, with countless Indigenous peoples and languages, and architecture that honours the gods. On the islands of Vietnam, Malaysia, Thailand and even landlocked Laos, you‚Äôll find thrilling scenery, fragrant street-food markets and irresistible villages. Here are eight of the best to explore.
Best for: beaches Thailand travellers escaping The White Lotus‚Ä¶

entry.title: Colossal crabs may hold clue to Amelia Earhart fate
entry.summary:
Amelia Earhart‚Äôs fate may be tied to the giant coconut crabs of Nikumaroro, in Kiribati.
Members of the National Geographic-sponsored expedition that last searched the island for traces of the pilot‚Äîfamous for being the first woman to fly solo across the Atlantic‚Äîknew to keep a wary eye out for the enormous crustaceans.
Adult coconut crabs are longer than a reporter‚Äôs notebook, wider than an archaeologist‚Äôs trowel, and roughly the same size as an explorer‚Äôs hiking boot. As the largest land invertebrate on the planet, coconut crabs can measure up to three feet across and clock in at over nine pounds. In short, they are too big.
During the day, when expedition scientists do most of their work on the Pacific oceanic atoll, the crabs are easily avoided. Those that emerge fro‚Ä¶

entry.title: 10 of the best hotels in Istanbul
entry.summary:
The palatial skyline of this ancient Silk Road capital features stays for all kinds of travellers. One of the world's most visited cities, Istanbul offers a wide range of hotels, from palatial seaside mansions to luxury shipyard conversions.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Stretching across two continents separated by the Bosphorus Strait, this ancient Silk Road city was once the capital of both the Christian Byzantine and Islamic Ottoman empires. Crumbling hammams rub shoulders with striking contemporary buildings, while the call to prayer from Hagia Sophia mosque can be heard from the 15th-century Grand Bazaar, as well as Michelin-starred restaurants. Istanbul is sewn together by a series of storied districts, which results in a varied hote‚Ä¶

entry.title: This spa town is perfect for exploring the UK's Peak District
entry.summary:
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Perched on the edge of the Peak District‚Äôs uplands, Buxton wears its heritage on its sleeve. Its Georgian crescents and Victorian halls recall an era when visitors came to ‚Äòtake the waters‚Äô from mineral springs that still flow today. It‚Äôs an old market town, and the centre remains full of independent shops and cafes. Take a day to explore on foot; little details reveal themselves as you go, whether it‚Äôs the splash of a pond in the Botanical Conservatory or the curve of a terrace in the glow of golden hour. The surrounding corner of Derbyshire has more architectural highlights, including grand stately homes just a 30-minute drive away. But Buxton‚Äôs biggest calling card is perhaps its location at the doorstep of the Peak ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Inside the fight to protect Canada‚Äôs most iconic bays
entry.summary:
A family of polar bears walks along the shoreline in Arviliit, also known as the Ottawa Islands, in northern Canada. In 2022, National Geographic Pristine Seas partnered with Oceans North for an expedition to the Canadian Arctic in support of Indigenous-led conservation. The expedition spanned seven weeks and 7,000 miles. A new documentary from the National Geographic Society and Oceans North spotlights how Inuit and Cree communities are creating marine protected areas in Canada‚Äôs north.
Flocks of geese soar through the sky in iconic V-formations, honking loudly. Wearing a matching camouflage jacket and pants, and a gun slung across his back, Edward Bearskin lifted his hands to his mouth and produced a convincing goose call. ‚ÄúI hunt geese for life. It‚Äôs part of my culture,‚Äù says Be‚Ä¶

entry.title: When the women of Iceland took a day off‚Äîand inspired the world
entry.summary:
The morning of October 24, 1975, started out differently than usual for 90 percent of women in Iceland. For once, they didn‚Äôt have the usual rush to make breakfast or get the children ready for school. The 60 percent of women who worked outside the home would not be going to their jobs either. They were going out‚Äîand leaving the men in their lives to fend for themselves.
The women of Iceland took to the streets that day 50 years ago to protest unfair employment practices, the wage gap, and the general devaluing of domestic labor. Without them, everyday life ground to a halt. Nurseries and schools shut down without their female workforces, as did big shops, theaters, and fishing factories. Men were forced to bring their children to the office and, later that day, easy-to-cook sausages ‚Ä¶

entry.title: 8 big cities with extraordinary green spaces
entry.summary:
Trade the concrete of downtown for a lush park to help calm your mind, a good habit for both locals and travelers. These urban oases, in cities from Barcelona to Tokyo, provide a calming break from the bright lights and crush of the crowds.
My family of five loves traveling to large cities, but the crowds, noise, and unpleasant smells can sometimes be overwhelming. That‚Äôs why, whenever we visit a city, we always make time to relax in a green space like a park or botanical garden.
Research shows that green spaces can help you de-stress from the city experience, explains Sandi Schwartz, author of Finding Ecohappiness: Fun Nature Activities to Help Your Kids Feel Happier and Calmer. ‚ÄúThe farther you get from the noisy urban center, the more nature acts as a buffer and helps you r‚Ä¶

entry.title: The ghost stories of ancient Rome
entry.summary:
The goddess Roma appears to Julius Caesar on the banks of the Rubicon. One of the most common genres of ancient Roman supernatural stories was the appearance of spectral figures like this one. Ghosts stories appear in several surviving texts from ancient Rome. What do they reveal about the people who told them?
Do you believe in ghosts? That‚Äôs what prominent Roman lawyer and statesman Pliny the Younger asked his friend in a letter around A.D. 100.
‚ÄúI should very much like to know whether you think there are such things as ghosts,‚Äù Pliny wrote, ‚Äúand whether they have their own shapes and some divine existence, or whether they are unreal images that take their forms from our own anxieties.‚Äù
Pliny was writing to his friend Sura, a Roman senator. To give Sura some food for th‚Ä¶

entry.title: NASA discovered a bacteria that can ‚Äòplay dead‚Äô
A 100-mile journey along Switzerland‚Äôs dinosaur highway
entry.summary:
Thousands of dinosaur footprints can be found in the Jura Mountains, a range between Switzerland and France. In Switzerland‚Äôs Jura Mountains, ancient limestone holds thousands of dinosaur footprints. A gravel route traces their path across ridges, valleys, and 150 million years of history.
We spot the first cliff early in the morning. The summer sun rises slowly, its deep indigo gradually fading into a soft peach. The world remains asleep, and we break the silence with heavy breathing and the sound of our tires crunching on the gravel road beneath us.
In the distance, the Alps glow‚Äîbut we are traveling through the Jura, a lesser-known mountain range that separates northwest Switzerland from France. The Jura are lower and gentler than the Alps and mostly covered in forests. The‚Ä¶

entry.title: These manuscripts brought Medieval beasts to life
entry.summary:
In the second or third century A.D., an anonymous author in Alexandria, Egypt, composed a text entitled Physiologus, or The Naturalist. The work was soon widely copied and comprised of 48 or 49 chapters. Each was dedicated to a specific animal and included an illustration, a description of its characteristics, and a story‚Äîpart natural observation, part imaginative anecdote‚Äîabout its behavior.
One such story, for example, features the lion. It was said that lion cubs were born lifeless and watched over by their mother until the father, king of the beasts, arrived and breathed life into them. This image gave rise to an allegorical reading steeped in Christian symbolism: the cub revived by the lion became a figure of Christ resurrected on the third day. While the lion embodied noble virt‚Ä¶

entry.title: ‚ÄòLet's finish the job‚Äô and end polio: WHO
entry.summary: Thirty-five years ago, polio, a highly infectious viral disease, paralysed around 350,000 children per year. Following a UN-led international push, that number is now less than 50.

Santorini‚Äôs volcano is hiding an explosive secret
entry.summary:
A man looks out across the Santorini caldera in the Aegean Sea, where a future eruption could be more explosive than scientists previously thought. Over 3,000 years ago, the eruption of Santorini‚Äôs volcano ended an ancient civilization. Scientists may know what the next big explosion could look like.
The Santorini volcano gives this Greek island in the Aegean Sea its undeniable aesthetic marvel. But it‚Äôs also at the center of a spectacularly violent origin story.
Arc-shaped Santorini has a flooded interior because, in the distant past, colossal eruptions have rapidly excavated a hole out of the island‚Äôs center. After each eruption, the Santorini volcano starts to recharge its magma supply, readying itself for another gigantic blast.

entry.title: Dinosaurs were thriving right up to the moment the asteroid hit
entry.summary:
Alamosaurus was one of the last dinosaurs from southern North American. Paleontologists have recently dated the rock formation from where it was found in New Mexico to around 340,000 years before the asteroid hit. Newly dated fossils from New Mexico challenge the idea that dinosaurs were in decline‚Äîand suggest instead they had formed flourishing communities.
Around 66 million years ago, during the Northern Hemisphere‚Äôs spring, a six-mile-wide asteroid struck what is now the Yucat√°n Peninsula. The resulting disaster drove 75 percent of Earth‚Äôs species to extinction, including nearly every dinosaur lineage except for beaked birds.
The impact was devastating. Its aftermath, apocalyptic. But what was happening right before the cataclysmic event?
Paleontologists have long deba‚Ä¶

entry.title: Could ‚Äòthe big one‚Äô in Cascadia trigger the San Andreas?
entry.summary:
This satellite-based model of Earth shows the tectonic boundaries (yellow lines) in the eastern Pacific Ocean. The San Andreas Fault and the Cascadia Subduction Zone both occur along the North American plate, beside the Pacific and Juan de Fuca plates respectively. Are two of the deadliest earthquake zones in North America linked? It's possible‚Äîbut controversial.
One of the most dangerous faults in the United States, the Cascadia Subduction Zone, may be able to trigger an earthquake on the San Andreas Fault, a new study says. But some scientists want more evidence.¬†
According to the paper, published in September in the journal Geosphere, deep-sea sediment cores taken along the West Coast offer evidence that the two fault systems have been synced up for much of the last 2,500 y‚Ä¶

entry.title: Discover Oman through its perfumes and ancient aromas
entry.summary:
The fragrant resin of Boswellia Sacra trees is harvested by cutting the bark. Across Oman‚Äôs mountains, wadis and coasts, the scents of rose and frankincense tell a tale that bridges the country‚Äôs past and present.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
‚ÄúThis perfume was first made for royalty.‚Äù The salesman at Amouage perfume factory in Muscat is pointing towards a 24-carat gold flask, a tiny, exquisite bottle shaped like a khanjar, Oman‚Äôs traditional dagger. ‚ÄúThere are 120 ingredients in here, with two in particular that really represent Oman: rose and frankincense,‚Äù he says.
The fragrance house was commissioned by Oman‚Äôs beloved late Sultan Qaboos bin Said al Said in 1983 and its name, Amouage, comes from the Arabic word for waves. It's fitti‚Ä¶

entry.title: Exploring England on two wheels‚Äîhow to plan a cycle tour
entry.summary:
England is a nation of bike enthusiasts and, as a result, possesses an excellent cycling infrastructure. Two-wheeled tourers have an impressively large choice of places to ride, whether it‚Äôs forests or fells, cities or cycle superhighways, canals or coasts. With the right gear and a good idea, you can zoom along wild coastlines, camp beside a Roman wall and find solitude high on windswept plains. Here‚Äôs how to plan the perfect English cycle tour.
Consider where you‚Äôd like to visit and use online resources to help plan the best itinerary. Cycle.travel has a range of comprehensive guides for on- and off-road cycle touring, as well as a detailed route finder. Take a look at Sustrans‚Äô National Cycle Network maps, which can also simplify planning your itinerary.
Before setting out o‚Ä¶

entry.title: Have orcas been sinking ships for millennia?
entry.summary:
A sixth-century Byzantine mosaic depicts an amphibious monster‚Äîthough it's unclear if this is the same one that was thought to have tormented the sailors of Constantinople by attacking and sinking their boats. The historian Procopius described how a creature called Porphyrios terrified sixth-century sailors for 50 years. But what was it?
‚ÄúIt sank many ships and troubled the passengers of many others.‚Äù
These words sound like they could have been written about White Gladis, the orca who has earned renown in recent years as the potential ringleader of killer whales ramming boats and ripping off their rudders.
But in fact this text was written by the Greek historian Procopius, who told of a terrible sea monster called Porphyrios that tormented the people of Byzantium for 50 y‚Ä¶

entry.title: World‚Äôs longest woolly rhino horn discovered in Siberia
entry.summary:
In the far-flung reaches of Yakutia, a rugged corner of Russia that bears the title of the coldest inhabited place on Earth, mysteries lurk beneath the frozen soil.
Roman Romanov, a local hunter, fisherman and fossil collector, uncovered one of those mysteries last summer. While walking along a stream in the tundra, he spotted something emerging from the melting permafrost: a skull and a massive, curved horn poking out of the ground.
Romanov dug up the frozen remains and took them to the Mammoth Museum in the regional capital of Yakutsk, where many creatures pulled from the icy ground are stored and studied. Scientists at the museum determined the skull belonged to a 19,700-year-old woolly rhino. When it roamed the area, it would have been as heavy as an SUV and cloaked in a shag‚Ä¶

entry.title: 9 perfect small-town getaways near Washington, D.C.
entry.summary:
Harper‚Äôs Ferry, West Virginia, is situated at the junction of the Potomac and Shenandoah Rivers. It‚Äôs a town you can cover in a day, but it‚Äôs worth spending an extra few days. Life moves quickly in the nation‚Äôs capital. But just across the Potomac, you can trade traffic for tranquility with these storybook escapes.
In Washington, D.C., where every corner buzzes with history, politics, and the unmistakable rhythms of go-go music, life moves at full throttle. Yet just across the Potomac River and beyond the Beltway, the pulse changes. Within a few hours, you can swap the motorcades for meadows, marble monuments for main streets, and the city skyline for tranquil shorelines. While Richmond and Baltimore often top weekend travel lists, for those craving something quieter and quainter, ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Forty migrants, including children, perish in Tunisia shipwreck
entry.summary: A shipwreck off Tunisia that claimed the lives of at least 40 African migrants has once again exposed the lethal risks of irregular sea crossings on routes to Europe, the UN migration agency said on Thursday.

entry.title: Ceasefire offers ‚Äòlifeline‚Äô but Gaza hospitals remain in ruins
entry.summary: Gaza‚Äôs health system remains in ruins despite the fragile ceasefire holding, with hundreds of thousands still facing urgent medical and humanitarian needs, the head of the World Health Organization (WHO) warned on Thursday.

entry.title: Millions pushed to ‚Äòbrink of survival‚Äô in Sudan
entry.summary: Over 900 days of brutal conflict, widespread human rights violations, famine, and the collapse of essential services have driven millions of people in Sudan to the ‚Äúbrink of survival‚Äù ‚Äì with women and children bearing the heaviest burden.

entry.title: Fragile Gaza ceasefire marks ‚Äòa momentous but precarious juncture,‚Äô UN envoy tells Security Council
entry.summary: The Gaza ceasefire provides a rare opportunity to end one of the most destructive phases of the wider Israel-Palestine conflict, the UN‚Äôs deputy Middle East envoy told the Security Council on Thursday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Security Council LIVE: Gaza ceasefire, aid crisis dominates agenda as ambassadors meet on the Middle East
entry.summary: The UN Security Council is meeting in New York to debate the Middle East. The session comes amid faltering progress on the fragile Gaza ceasefire and mounting humanitarian needs after two years of war, with famine still looming in parts of the territory. Ambassadors will likely discuss yesterday's ICJ advisory opinion affirming Israel‚Äôs obligation to allow agencies aid access under international law. Follow our in-depth live coverage from 10am; UN News app users can go here.

entry.title: Mentoring Under Pressure: How One Nigerian Woman Is Shaping the Next Generation of Investigative Reporters

entry.title: 'Java Man,‚Äô the first Homo erectus discovered, is finally going home
entry.summary:
The skull cap of 'Java Man' was discovered by Eug√®ne Dubois in 1891 in Trinil, East Java. It played a crucial role in our understanding of human evolution, and will be repatriated to Indonesia after more than a century in the Netherlands. Excavated with colonial labor and shipped to the Netherlands, the famous fossil is being repatriated to Indonesia along with 28,000 other fossils.
In 1866 Raden Saleh, a Javanese nobleman and naturalist painter, traveled to the eastern part of Java to see the so-called ‚Äúbattlefield of the giants.‚Äù
Local farmers there had found massive bones, which they said belonged to the giant demon king Arimba, a figure from the Javanese version of the Sanskrit epic, Mahabharata. Intrigued, Saleh visited ‚Äúthe battlefield‚Äù and identified the large bones as ‚Ä¶

entry.title: The striking ways that playing golf reshapes your body and brain
entry.summary:
Retirees play golf in Sun City, Arizona. Although it may seem like a leisurely pastime, studies show that golf offers a complete full-body workout that can even extend your life. Studies show that spending time on the links offers real benefits for cardiovascular health, cognition, and lifespan. ‚ÄúThe message is clear: Play golf and live longer.‚Äù
Golf may look like a leisurely pastime, but don‚Äôt be fooled by the unhurried pace or neatly trimmed greens. Beneath its calm exterior lies one of the most unexpectedly complete workouts and wellness boosts around.
‚ÄúOver 100 million people¬†worldwide now play golf, which is great for both individual and public health,‚Äù says Julia Kettinen, an exercise medicine lecturer at the University of Eastern Finland‚Äôs School of Medicine. ‚ÄúThe magic‚Ä¶

entry.title: Lucid dreams can help reduce anxiety. Here‚Äôs how.
entry.summary:
Lucid dreaming is the state of becoming aware of one's dream as it occurs. Lucid dreaming has been shown to reduce insomnia and anxiety, and even help people process their grief. But for most of us, it doesn‚Äôt come naturally.
A lucid dream is one in which the person is aware that they‚Äôre dreaming and can either exert some control over the dream, or passively observe its unfolding while maintaining awareness that it‚Äôs a dream. Some liken it to being in a movie and watching a movie at the same time.
Lucid dreamers have an opportunity to potentially influence their dream life, perhaps by consciously interrupting a nighttime narrative to rescript a new outcome. This can be especially helpful for reducing the frequency of nightmares in those who have them, according to research in ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Where to find the best sausage stands in Vienna
entry.summary:
Wieners are taken seriously in the Austrian capital as sausage stands like Wiener W√ºrstelstand serve their hot dogs alongside open mic nights and dance battles. Once a humble pit stop, the city‚Äôs sausage stands ‚Äî now inscribed on UNESCO‚Äôs Intangible Cultural Heritage list ‚Äî are reimagining tradition through bold flavours and contemporary flair.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
‚ÄúW√ºrstelst√§ndes are the heart of Vienna,‚Äù says Sebastian Neuschler, owner of Alles Wurscht, one of the city‚Äôs new-wave sausage stands, set just behind the Vienna Stock Exchange building. ‚ÄúThey allow people, from small children to 90-year-old grandmothers, to meet and connect ‚Äî bringing the city together.‚Äù
Vienna‚Äôs passion for sausages was ignited in 1805¬†when German‚Ä¶

entry.title: Been to Lisbon and Porto? Here‚Äôs where to go next
entry.summary:
Beyond the beaten path lie Portugal‚Äôs best-kept secrets, where hot springs still steam, ancient towers guard cork forests and rugged trails wind through volcanic craters. From the reviving spas of Chaves to the street art of Viseu, these lesser-known destinations offer truly memorable stays.
Best for: Bohemian beach days Tucked between pine groves and rice paddies an hour south of Lisbon, secluded Comporta has a laid-back rhythm beloved by celebrities and royals. Slow days are spent cycling boardwalks to empty beaches, sipping white port cocktails beneath cork oaks, and browsing ateliers in Casa da Cultura for linen fashion and hand-thrown ceramics. Dine on garlic clams at Sal or traditional Alentejo bread stew with rock lobster at Jncquoi Beach Club, then watch flamingos sweep acro‚Ä¶

entry.title: Which alcohol is the ‚Äòhealthiest‚Äô? Scientists have an answer.
entry.summary:
Marketed as low-calorie and hangover-proof, tequila has been reimagined as a ‚Äúclean‚Äù spirit. But research shows that the body processes all alcohol the same way‚Äîno matter the source. This popular spirit been touted as health-conscious‚Äîlow in sugar, hangover-proof, and even ‚Äúclean.‚Äù We asked experts to separate fact from fiction.
There are several unwritten ‚Äúrules‚Äù when it comes to alcohol: whiskey makes you aggressive, wine turns you emotional, and tequila? It‚Äôs the devil in a bottle.
But in recent years, tequila‚Äôs reputation has shifted. Once the fuel of spring-break regrets, it‚Äôs now touted as the ‚Äúcleanest‚Äù option at the bar‚Äîlow-calorie, additive-free, and even hangover-proof. But is there really such a thing as a healthier alcohol?
David Jernigan, assistant dean of pu‚Ä¶

entry.title: Too soon to declare inflation victory
entry.summary: Declarations have been made, but there‚Äôs not enough data yet to make such‚Ä¶ Tags: estimation, inflation, Washington Post

entry.title: UN appeals for stronger support for Syria, with millions still in need
entry.summary: As Syria‚Äôs humanitarian needs soar and aid funding dries up, UN officials urged the Security Council on Wednesday to step up support, warning that millions face continuing hardship even as the country rebuilds its political institutions.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Green light for Gang Suppression Force tells Haitians ‚Äòthey are not alone‚Äô, Security Council hears
entry.summary: The people of Haiti have not given up and ‚Äútheir fortitude gives us hope,‚Äù the UN Special Representative to the country told the Security Council on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Russian strikes on Ukraine kill at least six civilians, injure dozens
entry.summary: Russian forces carried out ‚Äúanother massive wave of overnight attacks‚Äù targeting energy facilities, the UN said on Wednesday, killing and injuring civilians ‚Äì including children.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Security Council LIVE: UN discusses next phase to curb Haiti gang violence, step up aid
entry.summary: Following renewal of the Security Council‚Äôs sanctions regime in Haiti and a resolution to create a new Gang Suppression Force to combat the scourge of gang violence, ambassadors heard this afternoon from the top UN official in the country. In his first briefing as head of the UN office in Haiti (BINUH), Carlos Ruiz Massieu reported on latest developments, as brutal violence and insecurity continues to rage, increasing pressure on diplomats to act fast and decisively to protect millions of Haitians facing impunity and chaos. UN News app users can follow live coverage here.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Israel is obliged to let aid flow into Occupied Palestinian Territory, says World Court
entry.summary: The International Court of Justice (ICJ) says that Israel must uphold its responsibilities as the ‚Äúoccupying power‚Äù by ensuring aid can flow freely and by respecting the rights of the UN and other humanitarian agencies working in the Occupied Palestinian Territory.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Most major methane leak alerts ignored despite climate threat
entry.summary: UN satellite tracking has greatly improved detection of major methane leaks ‚Äì a gas responsible for about a third of global warming ‚Äì yet companies and governments are acting on only around 12 per cent of alerts.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Four winters on, UN in Ukraine continues to deliver aid under fire
entry.summary: As Ukraine enters its fourth winter since the beginning of the full-scale Russian invasion in 2022, the United Nations remains committed to providing aid for embattled civilians across the country.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: New forum builds on Sevilla pledges to tackle global debt crisis
entry.summary: A new UN-backed forum launched on Wednesday to help developing nations escape the weight of unsustainable debt ‚Äì which has left more than three billion people worldwide living in economies forced to spend more on repayments than health or education.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Climate science and early warnings key to saving lives
entry.summary: No country is safe from the devastating impacts of extreme weather ‚Äî and saving lives means making early-warning systems accessible to all, UN chief Ant√≥nio Guterres said on Wednesday.

entry.summary: The sprawling Stanley Park National Historic Site is a 1,000-acre natural escape with trails, gardens, and an aquarium. British Columbia‚Äôs biggest city is co-hosting the FIFA World Cup in 2026‚Äîbut that‚Äôs only one reason to visit. Here are the best places to eat, where to stay, and how to explore this gem in 2026. https://interactives.natgeofe.com/high-touch/ngtravel-2510-botw-spotlights/builds/main/html/_graphic.html British Columbia‚Äôs biggest city is a rugged, outdoorsy, escape. Set on the edge of the Pacific Ocean, it boasts breaching orcas and massive humpback whales, towering Douglas firs, the sky-scraping North Shore Mountains, and thousands of acres of natural parkland. Sustainability filters naturally into every facet of daily life, and Indigenous tourism offerings plac‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why trigger points cause so much pain‚Äîand how you can relieve it
entry.summary:
A trigger point is a discrete, hyperirritable nodule (like a ‚Äúknot‚Äù) that is palpable in a taut band of muscle‚Äîand it can produce pain in a particular spot or in another part of the body. Most people experience it as an ache or a stab of pain when these locations are touched or pressed.
Recently, trigger points have been implicated in various conditions, including myofascial pain syndrome (a chronic disorder involving the muscles and the surrounding connective tissue); tension-type headaches (particularly in women);¬†migraine headaches; chronic neck pain; and low back pain.
While the formal term ‚Äúmyofascial trigger point‚Äù was coined in the 1950s, research investigating the underlying causes and effective treatments is relatively new.
That‚Äôs a positive development because trig‚Ä¶

entry.title: What it takes to be America‚Äôs top house cat
entry.summary:
Walking into the 2025 Cat Fancier Association International Cat Show & Expo, there is no mistaking where you are.¬†
On the main stage, performers belt out Taylor Swift‚Äôs song ‚Äú22,‚Äù but they have replaced the lyrics with meows‚Äîit‚Äôs ‚ÄúCat-aoke,‚Äù after all‚Äîand they are joined by a trio of dancing, cat-themed Furries. Nearby, there‚Äôs a four-foot-tall cat tower with two adult humans sitting atop cosplaying as Rum Tum Tugger and Electra from the Broadway musical¬†Cats. They mew as I walk past.¬†
Vendors sell cat houses that look like more like condos, or even the White House. A booth demonstrates a $900 futuristic-looking box that promises to dry your freshly-bathed pet quickly and quietly.¬†
It's cats all the way down here at one of the largest cat shows on the planet, organized by th‚Ä¶
