entry.title: What it takes to tend the world‚Äôs deadliest garden
entry.summary:
The keepers of a poison garden¬†on the grounds next to Alnwick Castle in Northumberland, England, anticipate a great many fainters every year. The garden, the largest of its kind, sits behind stately iron gates embellished with skulls and is packed with more than a hundred varieties of plants so deadly that you can‚Äôt enter without supervision.
As tours set off, guides warn visitors not to touch, lick, or pick as they learn about poisoners from history and see the brews and cuttings that served as their weapons of choice. There‚Äôs the Teacup Poisoner, who kicked off his infamous murder spree by dosing his sister with¬†Atropa belladonna.¬†And Doctor Death, a physician convicted of murdering 15 of his patients with a drug derived from the opium poppy. Every so often‚Äîcrunch!‚Äîanother guest hit‚Ä¶

entry.title: 8 of Brazil's best festivals beyond Rio
entry.summary:
Elaborately costumed Samba dancers are the stars of Rio de Janeiro's many street festivals and parties. Brazil is passionate about celebrations, its enormous cultural diversity resulting in a rich calendar of events held throughout the year ‚Äî here are some of the ones to look forward to beyond Rio.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In a country known for celebrations ‚Äì chief among them the Rio Carnival, which takes place annually between February and March ‚Äì there‚Äôs plenty to look forward to throughout the year. From the riotous to the muddy, here are some of the best festivals and celebrations.
This unique festival, held in the photogenic Costa Verde town of Paraty, coincides with Rio‚Äôs Carnival but couldn‚Äôt be more different. Instead o‚Ä¶

entry.title: Gaza: Aid efforts continue as UN teams start clearing up to 60 million tonnes of debris
entry.summary: The UN on Monday said it was encouraged by renewed Gaza ceasefire commitments, warning that recent violence risked undermining fragile progress, as recovery efforts ‚Äì including a large-scale rubble removal project ‚Äì slowly gain momentum across the war-ravaged enclave.

entry.summary: To Sudan, where the people of government held El Fasher in the west of the war-torn country remain trapped without food, water or medical care, UN aid coordinators, OCHA, said on Monday.

entry.summary: Millions of people worldwide have been positively impacted by the work of the United Nations and some of their stories are being highlighted at an exhibition at the global organization‚Äôs New York headquarters.

entry.title: $31 trillion debt is holding back developing countries, UN trade summit hears
entry.summary: Holding the line on the existing rules-based international trading system remains an essential challenge if the world is the keep a damaging tariff war at bay, a top UN trade official said on Monday.

entry.title: Britain's bonfire night events worth travelling for
entry.summary:
This raucous, torch-lit parade in Lewes features brass bands, bagpipes and firecrackers as well as a procession of giant, caricature effigies. Get winter off to a cracking start with our pick of the November festivities, from fireworks in London to flaming tar barrels in Devon.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
‚ÄòRemember, remember, the fifth of November‚Äô, goes the old nursery rhyme, ‚Äògunpowder, treason and plot.‚Äô It‚Äôs a memorably succinct summary of the events of that very night in 1605, when Catholic rebel Guy Fawkes tried to blow up the Houses of Parliament and assassinate England‚Äôs Protestant king, James I. The monarch‚Äôs survival has been marked ever since and celebrations have evolved over the centuries. Traditionally, Guy‚Äôs effigy was burn‚Ä¶

entry.title: The Louvre has a wild history of being robbed in broad daylight
entry.summary:
People gather around the Mona Lisa painting in Paris, three years after it was stolen from the Louvre by Vincenzo Peruggia in 1911. The theft is one of the most famous in the museum's history. One of the most infamous heists in the cultural institution‚Äôs history was the 1911 theft of the Mona Lisa‚Äîwhen Pablo Picasso numbered among the suspects.
It took just four minutes for a group of audacious thieves to pull off what may have been one of the most daring crimes in modern art: the theft of Napoleonic-era jewels from the Louvre in Paris on the morning of October 19.
The heist, which took place while the museum was open to the public, involved a variety of jewels once owned by members of the French monarchy, including an emerald necklace and earrings that Napoleon gave his s‚Ä¶

entry.title: Chasing rhythms in Detroit‚Äîinside the city's vibrant music scene
entry.summary: Thanks to the revolution of the motorcar assembly line, Detroit became the beating heart of American industry in the 20th century ‚Äî ranking among the richest cities in the world. Beyond industry, the Motor City has long been a beacon of creativity, with a conveyor belt of musical talent that never stopped rolling. From soul-stirring legends such as Aretha Franklin and Stevie Wonder to modern icons such as Eminem and The White Stripes, this Midwestern city gifted the world some of its brightest musical stars. Today, that creative energy still pulses through Detroit ‚Äî not just in music, but in the bold flavours of its burgeoning restaurant scene and a flourishing street art movement that draws in visitors from around the world. Through it all, the Motor City keeps on moving and grooving to t‚Ä¶

entry.title: What happened the last time the French crown jewels were stolen
entry.summary:
Known by awed gemologists simply as ‚Äúthe Blue,‚Äù the world‚Äôs biggest blue diamond first vanished in a jewel heist during the turmoil of revolutionary Paris in 1792. Since then, it has resurfaced and disappeared several times around Europe and across the Atlantic. Historians and jewelers have finally ended this treasure hunt that lasted more than two centuries.
Most diamonds are prized for colorlessness, but this remarkable gem stood out for its distinctive deep blue hue. Discovered in India and brought to France in the 17th century, the stone measured a whopping 115 carats‚Äîa rare heavyweight in gemological terms.
The diamond came to the attention of France‚Äôs Louis XIV, who bought it in 1668. To craft a fitting symbol for the Sun King, Louis had it cut, reducing it to 69 carats‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to plan the perfect French Riviera tour by train
entry.summary:
Menton‚Äôs old town overlooks the Mediterranean and welcomed the first sleeper train passengers on the French Riviera in 1886. Take the train for a laid-back tour of the C√¥te d‚ÄôAzur‚Äôs glitzy cities and lesser-known towns, jumping off to buy a slice of Pissaladi√®re, visit a museum or dip your toes in the sea.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
In 1886, passengers on the Calais-M√©diterran√©e Express were among the first to ride a sleeper service from Paris to the town of Menton on the French Riviera. They bedded down in the capital and woke up speeding along the coast, prickly pears blooming by the tracks, flashes of the Mediterranean sparkling in the first light of morning. The train was discontinued some 20 years ago, but with sleeper services enj‚Ä¶

entry.title: What happens when Afghan women and girls go offline?
entry.summary: Nearly 70,000 women in Afghanistan tune in to Radio Femme ‚Äì an all-female-run online and traditionally broadcast radio station which brings education and awareness of rights to women and girls across the province.

entry.title: What it's like to night dive on the Great Barrier Reef
entry.summary:
The Great Barrier Reef is the world‚Äôs largest living structure, so big, it can be seen from space. Stretching almost 1,500 miles, the Great Barrier Reef is so vast that just 20% has been surveyed. With tourism funding millions in conservation each year, seeing the reef ‚Äî guided by expert Master Reef Guides ‚Äî may be the key to helping save it.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The first time a giant trevally fish hits me on the forehead, I freeze. We‚Äôre 39ft below the surface of the ocean at dusk, the inky black water lit only by our torches. Thick with plankton, the beams cut through the white-speckled dark like headlights in a snowstorm. Enormous fish in their hundreds ‚Äî silver, coral pink and coal black ‚Äî all dart past my face, close enough t‚Ä¶

entry.title: Do natural sleep aids like melatonin and magnesium work?
entry.summary:
Many people swear by a cup of chamomile tea to help them fall asleep at night. But scientists say the evidence is mixed about the effects of natural sleep remedies like this medicinal herb‚Äîseen here growing in a field in Mecklenburg-Vorpommern, Germany. Many people swear by natural sleep aids to help them fall asleep. But experts say the evidence is much less convincing.
Natural sleep aids like melatonin and magnesium supplements, valerian root, and tart cherry juice are often touted by people faced with sleepless nights. But can they actually help you fall and stay asleep?
According to the National Academy of Medicine, 50 to 70 million people in the United States face chronic sleep issues‚Äîand collectively, Americans spend $67 billion dollars on sleep aids every year. Despite ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Beverly and Dereck Joubert on what makes a good image
entry.summary:
Red-billed oxpeckers create a winged dance around this giraffe in Kenya‚Äôs Olare Motorogi Conservancy, eating ticks and pests off her body while stealing her hair to make their own nests (2023). The legendary pair share their thoughts on the craft of photography, what goes into a great shot, and what they hope for the future of wildlife.
More than 40 years of photographs by¬†renowned conservationist¬†Beverly Joubert have somehow been winnowed down to a few hundred of her most powerful shots for a new book,¬†Wild Eye: A Life in Photographs. An elephant wading through a pond that shimmers like hammered gold, a melee of wildebeests fording a river, and I-want-to-go-to-there natural landscapes‚Äîthese are just some of the¬†photos that grace¬†its pages.
Joubert and her filmmaker husband, D‚Ä¶

entry.title: GIJN Webinar: Tips and Tools for Uncovering Online Scams
entry.summary: In this GIJN webinar, investigative journalists from around the world will gain practical strategies and tools for tracking, verifying, and reporting on online scams. Whether you‚Äôre new to the topic or looking to deepen your expertise, this session will provide advice for impactful reporting on one of the world‚Äôs most urgent issues.

entry.title: Here‚Äôs how to see a rare green comet this week
entry.summary:
Comet C/2025 A6 (Lemmon), captured from the Dark Sky Alqueva Observatory in Portugal on October 2, 2025, glows green as it nears its closest approach to Earth. Here‚Äôs how to see this rare green comet before it disappears for a millennium. Comet C/2025 A6 (Lemmon) is this year‚Äôs brightest comet visible from Earth‚Äîan icy relic from the solar system‚Äôs origins that won‚Äôt return until the next millennium.
This week, Earth gets a front-row seat to one of the solar system‚Äôs oldest relics. On October 21, Comet C/2025 A6 (Lemmon) will pass closest to Earth‚Äîits first and only appearance for more than a thousand years.
‚ÄúComets are very common, but Comet Lemmon is definitely the best comet to view from Earth this year,‚Äù says Rhonda Stroud, the director of the Center for Meteorite Studies ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why Rome‚Äôs origin myth leaves more questions than answers
entry.summary:
It is unusual for a city to boast a true founding event. Such occasions are rare, mostly taking place when a conqueror decides to create a city bearing his name. This was the case with Alexander the Great, who established more than 20 cities in the fourth century B.C. On the other hand, Rome, much like Athens, was more likely the result of synoecism‚Äîthe gradual aggregation of neighboring villages that, driven by the need for defense and trade, eventually coalesce into a single community under a monarchy. However, the legends of Rome‚Äôs founding are far more riveting.
The wisest words on the matter come from the Roman historian Livy, in the opening of his monumental Ab Urbe Condita (From the Founding of the City): ‚ÄúI intend neither to affirm nor refute the legends concerning the time be‚Ä¶

entry.summary: As the disarmament team approached, combatants from the Retour, R√©clamation et R√©habilitation (3R) armed group stood in two orderly lines expectantly, youthful faces and greying heads alike.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Security Council renews Haiti sanctions
entry.summary: The UN Security Council unanimously adopted a resolution on Friday that renews sanctions in Haiti for another year as armed gangs continue to terrorize the population.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Talks on net zero shipping framework shelved as nations fail to reach consensus
entry.summary: Talks at the International Maritime Organization (IMO) on adopting new global rules to cut greenhouse gas emissions from ships ended Friday without agreement, as delegates voted to defer a decision for 12 months amid sharp divisions over the proposed Net-Zero Framework.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: World News in Brief: Airstrikes in Lebanon, hope in CAR, a call to ban lead-based paints
entry.summary: The Security Council on Friday welcomed Lebanese Government efforts to exercise full national sovereignty through the Lebanese Armed Forces (LAF), as the UN warned that peacekeepers are continuing to find unauthorised weapons caches in the south.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN faces ‚Äòrace to bankruptcy‚Äô as Guterres unveils sharply reduced 2026 budget
entry.summary: The United Nations faces a ‚Äúrace to bankruptcy‚Äù unless Member States pay their dues in full and on time, Secretary-General Ant√≥nio Guterres warned on Friday, presenting a sharply reduced $3.238 billion regular budget for 2026.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: UN urges opening of all Gaza crossings to deliver three-month food supply
entry.summary: The UN World Food Programme (WFP) has warned food aid cannot reach everyone in Gaza unless all border crossings are opened, particularly in the north where famine was declared in August.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Haiti is under a UN arms embargo: So why are 500,000 illegal weapons in circulation?
entry.summary: Up to 500,000 illegal weapons ranging from handguns to battlefield-grade semi-automatic rifles are thought to be in the hands of gangs in Haiti, even though the Caribbean country has been under a UN arms embargo for the last three years.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Groundbreaking report reveals powerful link between poverty and the climate crisis
entry.summary: Nearly 80 per cent of the world‚Äôs poor ‚Äì 887 million people ‚Äì live in regions that are exposed to extreme heat, flooding and other climate hazards, highlighting the urgent need for global action to address the issue.

entry.title: The world's oldest theatre has closed. Here's where to visit instead
entry.summary:
Athens' Odeon of Herodes Atticus was built in AD 161. Athens‚Äô Odeon of Herodes Atticus has closed for a three-year renovation, but the show must go on, so here are nine equally notable theatres to check out in the meantime.
This article was produced by¬†National Geographic Traveller¬†(UK).
Located at the foot of the Acropolis in the Greek capital of Athens, the Odeon of Herodes Atticus was built in AD 161. Now that it‚Äôs closed for an extensive restoration project, we take a look at some other esteemed theatres around the world that are well worth a visit, from historic wonders to modern marvels.
Though the current building dates from 1929, a theatre has stood on his spot since 1610, making it Japan‚Äôs oldest playhouse. Widely regarded as the first kabuki theatre (which u‚Ä¶

entry.title: What do long flights do to our bodies?
entry.summary:
Long flights can impact your body and health beyond just making you feel jet lagged. From dehydration to indigestion, here are the health risks of long-haul flights‚Äîand how to survive them.
Long-haul flights can do a number on your body. If you‚Äôve taken one recently, especially in a seat with limited recline, the discomfort of the experience is likely still painfully fresh.
While airline seat size and pitch (aka legroom) have¬†shrunk since the 1990s, time passengers spend in the air is noticeably increasing.¬†
When Qantas launches its nonstop Sydney-to-London route in late 2025, it will be the longest flight in the world at 20 hours of flying time. Current honors go to Singapore Airlines‚Äô New York-to-Singapore route, which clocks in at over 18 hours.¬†

entry.title: The mystery behind the Bermuda Triangle
entry.summary:
In Wilhelm Blaeu‚Äôs circa 1650 Atlas illustrating the Caribbean Sea, the Bermuda Triangle is indicated between the Bermuda Archipelago, Miami, and Puerto Rico. Giant squid? Wild weather? Here‚Äôs what may‚Äîand may not‚Äîbe behind the strange disappearances in the Bermuda Triangle.
The Bermuda Triangle is an area of the ocean roughly bounded by Miami, Bermuda, and Puerto Rico. No one keeps statistics, but in the last century, numerous ships and planes have simply vanished without a trace within this imaginary triangle.
Unusual features of the area had been noted in the past. Christopher Columbus wrote in his log about bizarre compass bearings in the area. In March 1918, the U.S. naval vessel the U.S.S. Cyclops disappeared without a trace.
But the region didn‚Äôt get its name until‚Ä¶

entry.title: The Grand Egyptian Museum is opening in full‚Äîhere's what to know
entry.summary:
Found within the walls of the Grand Egyptian Museum are tens of thousands of artefacts. The Grand Egyptian Museum is set to open in its entirety ‚Äî from pyramid views to Tutankhamun‚Äôs treasures, here‚Äôs what you can expect.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
The Grand Egyptian Museum in Cairo has been heralded as one of the biggest cultural openings of the year. Located near the Pyramids of Giza, this cultural colossus is the world‚Äôs largest institution dedicated to a single civilisation, with almost 872,000sq feet of floor space displaying tens of thousands of artefacts. Its opening date was planned for well over a decade ago, then shifted to 2018 and beyond, with a phased launch adding to the timeline. Now, it seems finally ready to open in its ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why the definition of ‚Äòmoderate‚Äô drinking is changing
entry.summary:
For decades, the idea of¬†‚Äúmoderate¬†drinking,‚Äù such as a glass of wine with dinner or weekend cocktails, has been framed as part of a healthy lifestyle‚Äîa ritual that might even protect the heart. However, as research is showing, there‚Äôs genuinely no ‚Äúsafe‚Äù level of alcohol consumption.
‚ÄúDespite¬†our wish that would be the case, no study has ever demonstrated a protective or beneficial effect of alcohol,‚Äù says Patricia Molina, a physiology researcher at Louisiana State University, Health Sciences Center, whose research focuses on the impact that alcohol has on the body.¬†
That doesn‚Äôt mean every sip carries equal risk‚Äîbut it does raise a new question: What does ‚Äúmoderate drinking‚Äù actually mean, and how much is too much? While no amount of alcohol is entirely risk-free, there are lev‚Ä¶

entry.title: Want to survive in the dark ocean? Use a stinging shield.
entry.summary: A ray-finned fish of the Carangidae family is seen with a tube anemone larva. Nighttime underwater photos show fish hanging out with jellyfish and anemones ‚Äî perhaps seeking their protection. Against the blackness of water at night, the pomfret looked like it had blown a big bubble from gum. Instead, the fish had the larva of an anemone sticking out of its mouth.¬†¬† This was just one example of fish interacting with anemones in surprising ways that scientists¬†documented in a new study¬†in the¬†Journal of Fish Biology. Photos taken by divers at night ‚Äî during so-called ‚Äúblackwater diving‚Äù ‚Äî show young fish hanging out with and even holding potentially dangerous anemones, possibly using them as shields.¬† Researchers say this behavior may help the tiny fish avoid becomin‚Ä¶

entry.title: What really happened to the Library of Alexandria?
entry.summary: The 1876 painting Incendie Alexandrie by Hermann Goll depicts the destruction of the Library of Alexandria. When the Library burned, the massive collection of works from the ancient world vanished, including works of literature, philosophy, science, and history from various cultures like Greece, Egypt, Persia, and Mesopotamia. The loss of the ancient world's greatest repository of knowledge has been mourned for centuries‚Äîbut Julius Caesar may not really be to blame. As flames engulfed the Library of Alexandria, the ancient world‚Äôs greatest repository of human knowledge vanished. But who lit the match? It‚Äôs one of history‚Äôs most, well, burning questions, and with good reason‚Äîthe library was one of history‚Äôs most important institutions in education and culture.¬† Despite b‚Ä¶

entry.title: These 10 industrial American cities have had a glow up
entry.summary:
Pittsburgh named one of its Three Sisters Bridges after local native and pop-art artist Andy Warhol. The Andy Warhol Bridge leads directly to a museum (Andy Warhol Museum), which has an extensive collection of his work. From former factory hubs to shipping centers, these cities offer big-time culture, vibes, and amenities, and are attracting a new wave of visitors.
After decades in decline, a handful of flyover or underrated cites are now attracting first-time visitors. With careful urban planning, corporate support, and community collaboration, these cities are nodding to their pasts while moving toward a more modern, and in some cases, sustainable future. Here are 10 industrial cities emerging as prime travel destinations.
Best for: Southern sophisticates Once Birmingham‚Äôs‚Ä¶

entry.title: Neuroscientists are starting to take miracles seriously
entry.summary:
In 2007, at Memorial Hospital in Rhode Island, a premature baby was born by C-section after being severely deprived of oxygen in the womb. A couple hours later, his heartbeat slowed until it was nearly undetectable. The attending doctor prayed over the baby, directing his plea to Salvador Valera Parra, a priest who died in Spain in 1889. Moments later, the baby‚Äôs heart started beating. Despite the lack of oxygen, the boy grew up to be a healthy young man. Eighteen years later, in July of this year, Pope Leo XIV announced that the recovery was, officially, a miracle.
The Vatican has a miracle investigation office, the Dicastery for the Causes of Saints, established in the 16th Century. The Dicastery‚Äôs role is to determine whether a person can rightfully be canonized. As part of that pr‚Ä¶

entry.title: UN condemns Madagascar military takeover, urges return to constitutional order
entry.summary: The UN has condemned Madagascar‚Äôs military takeover, calling for the immediate restoration of constitutional order following last week‚Äôs ouster of President Andry Rajoelina.

entry.title: Funding crisis forces deep cuts to UN peacekeeping missions
entry.summary: A severe funding shortfall is threatening to cripple UN peacekeeping operations worldwide, with the Organization warning that it will have to scale back patrols, close field offices and repatriate thousands of ‚Äòblue helmets‚Äô due to delayed payments from Member States.

entry.title: World Food Day LIVE: The task of feeding the world
entry.summary: Amid the destruction of the Second World War, nations responded to the danger of hunger and malnutrition by creating the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) on 16 October 1945. The UN agency celebrates this achievement as World Food Day every year on its birthday, recognizing the work of all those who are committed to ensuring food for everyone. We‚Äôll be bringing you the highlights live from FAO throughout the day. UN News app users can follow coverage here.

entry.title: American becomes the first to ski down Everest‚Äôs hardest route
entry.summary:
On October 15 American mountaineer Jim Morrison, 50, became the first person to ski the North Face of Mount Everest (29,032 feet) via its most challenging and elusive line, a linkup of the Hornbein and Japanese Couloirs. At 12:45 p.m. local time Morrison reached Everest‚Äôs peak via the same route after six and a half weeks on the mountain and a grueling¬†summit push. With him were 11 other climbers, including fixers, Sherpas and a film crew led by photographer and National Geographic Explorer Jimmy Chin.
Chin and Chai Vasarhelyi, who won an Oscar for the 2018 film "Free Solo,‚Äù are directing a National Geographic documentary film on Morrison's achievement.
After their summit photos, Morrison spread the ashes of his late partner Hilaree Nelson, who died almost exactly three years ago‚Ä¶

entry.title: Can you guess what you‚Äôre seeing in this extreme close-up?
entry.summary:
They say beauty is in the eye of the beholder, but there is so much the eye cannot see. At the smallest scales, our world takes on an almost alien quality. Microphotography can bring these hidden marvels of the natural world to light, illuminating even the most minute of details.
For more than 50 years, the Nikon Small World competition has celebrated the art of microphotography. Among this year‚Äôs honorees are images that defy the imagination.
Take the arresting image at the top of this page. Is it a clutch of translucent frog spawn, or perhaps green pearls of slime? In fact it is a close-up of microscopic algae spheres that appear trapped within a droplet of water. Incredibly, each green sphere is itself a colony made up of as many as 50,000 cells. The image‚Äîwhich was taken by c‚Ä¶

entry.title: Discovery of fossilized hand may unlock an ancient mystery
entry.summary: The fossilized hand of a male Paranthropus boisei from Lake Turkana, Kenya, was found together with parts of a skull and a handful of teeth, suggesting that the hominin was capable of making and using stone tools.  Some sixty years after her grandmother discovered ‚ÄúNutcracker Man,‚Äù Louise Leakey unearths his long-lost hand‚Äîreviving a family debate about ancient toolmaking. National Geographic Explorer-at-Large Louise Leakey grew up hearing about the July morning in 1959 when her grandmother‚Äîpaleoanthropologist Mary Leakey‚Äîdiscovered a 1.8-million-year-old hominin skull in Oldupai Gorge (originally misnamed Olduvai) in Tanzania. After spotting fossilized teeth lodged in a rock, Mary drove straight back to camp to tell her husband Louis Leakey, who had stayed be‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to spend a perfect day in Helsinki
entry.summary:
The Lasipalatsi Square at Amos Rex museum is an extension to the modern art collection housed indoors. The Finnish capital is defined by the nature around it and the creative spirit of its people. This itinerary explores both traits, with a visit to a sprawling cultural complex, a bike ride along the coast and a happy hour with views.
This article was produced by National Geographic Traveller (UK).
Finnish people living in Helsinki ‚Äî a capital set at 60 degrees north, on a peninsula surrounded by Baltic waters ‚Äî don‚Äôt simply brave the elements. Instead, they revel in cold plunges, rejoice in the warmth of cedar-lined saunas and take inspiration from the wild, forested surroundings. The city fabric reflects its link to the environment, and visiting is a masterclass in living ‚Ä¶

entry.title: Fraudulent disability claims through Veterans Affairs
entry.summary: For the Washington Post, Craig Whitlock, Lisa Rein, and Caitlin Gilbert examine court‚Ä¶ Tags: disability, fraud, Veterans Affairs, Washington Post

entry.title: Methodology
entry.summary: About Pew Research Center‚Äôs Spring 2025 Global Attitudes Survey Results for the survey are based on a mix of telephone, face-to-face and online interviews conducted under the direction of Gallup, Langer Research Associates and Social Research Centre. The results are based on national samples, unless otherwise noted. Read more about our international survey methodology and [‚Ä¶] The post Methodology appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.summary: This report is a collaborative effort based on the input and analysis of the following individuals. Jacob Poushter, Associate Director, Global Attitudes ResearchMoira Fagan, Research AssociateManolo Corichi, Research Analyst Julia Armeli, Research AssistantDorene Asare-Marfo, Senior Panel ManagerPeter Bell, Associate Director, Design and ProductionJanakee Chavda, Associate Digital ProducerLaura Clancy, Research AnalystJonathan Evans, Senior ResearcherJanell Fetterolf, Senior [‚Ä¶] The post Acknowledgments appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix B: Political categorization
entry.summary: For this analysis, we grouped people into two political categories: those who support the governing political party (or parties) in their country, and those who do not. These categories were coded based on the party or parties in power at the time the survey was fielded and on respondents‚Äô answers to a question asking which [‚Ä¶] The post Appendix B: Political categorization appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Appendix A: Classifying European political parties
entry.summary: Classifying parties as populist Although experts generally agree that populist political leaders or parties display high levels of anti-elitism, definitions of populism vary. We use three measures to classify populist parties: anti-elite ratings from the 2019 Chapel Hill Expert Survey (CHES), Norris‚Äô Global Party Survey and The PopuList. We define a party as populist when [‚Ä¶] The post Appendix A: Classifying European political parties appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 4. Trust in the EU, U.S. and China to regulate use of AI
entry.summary: More people across 25 countries trust the EU to regulate AI effectively than trust the U.S. or China. The post 4. Trust in the EU, U.S. and China to regulate use of AI appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 3. Trust in own country to regulate use of AI
entry.summary: A median of 55% of adults in 25 countries trust in their country to regulate AI effectively. Trust is highest in India and lowest in Greece. The post 3. Trust in own country to regulate use of AI appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 2. Concern and excitement about AI
entry.summary: A median of 34% of adults in 25 countries are mainly concerned about AI's growing use in daily life, while a median of 16% are mainly excited. The post 2. Concern and excitement about AI appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: 1. AI awareness around the world
entry.summary: A median of 34% of adults in 25 countries have heard a lot about AI, with frequent internet users and younger people among the likeliest to say so. The post 1. AI awareness around the world appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: How People Around the World View AI
entry.summary: Most adults across 25 countries are aware of AI, and people are generally more concerned than excited about its effects on daily life. The post How People Around the World View AI appeared first on Pew Research Center.

entry.title: Revealing America‚Äôs brutal new firestorms
entry.summary:
Today‚Äôs fires are different.¬†Blazes have scarred and scorched the western United States for ages, but for scientists who study extreme climate events, like UCLA‚Äôs Daniel Swain, the wildfires are now defying historic precedent, moving and growing with a devastating intensity. As Swain puts it, these new fires are doing ‚Äúseemingly impossible things.‚Äù
Take Northern California‚Äôs 2020 ‚Äúgigafire,‚Äù the first in the state‚Äôs modern fire-tracking history to burn more than a million acres, a footprint larger than Rhode Island. Its size wasn‚Äôt unprecedented. The speed of the destruction was. ‚ÄúTwo hundred years ago, you probably would have seen million-acre fires, sometimes in California,‚Äù Swain says. ‚ÄúThey wouldn‚Äôt have burned a million acres in a few days. It would have taken months.‚Äù (Inside Ca‚Ä¶

entry.title: Trapped inside the Taliban's Afghanistan
entry.summary:
When Iranian photographer Hashem Shakeri returned to Kabul in August 2022, it had been less than a year since his first visit to Afghanistan‚Äôs capital. And it was less than a year since the Taliban, driven out two decades prior by a U.S.-led invasion, had seized control of Afghanistan. He found himself standing in what already felt like a different country. ‚ÄúThe sheer depth of this darkness, the uncertainty, and the inversion of everything was deeply unsettling to me,‚Äù he recalls.¬†
Shakeri‚Äôs project, aptly titled ‚ÄúStaring into the Abyss,‚Äù is a collection of deeply moving visuals capturing the slow-motion decay of dreams amid a rapid societal collapse. Afghanistan is, in many ways, a country not unlike his own. Growing up in Iran, with a shared heritage and culture, and even a common l‚Ä¶

entry.title: UN rights chief hails Bangladesh prosecutions over enforced disappearances
entry.summary: Bangladesh has begun legal proceedings against security officials accused of sanctioning enforced disappearances and torture under the previous government ‚Äì a move UN human rights chief Volker T√ºrk called ‚Äúan important step towards accountability.‚Äù

entry.title: Afghan quake aftermath: Children facing heightened risk from disease
entry.summary: Over 212,000 Afghan children are now at risk of acute watery diarrhoea and other deadly waterborne diseases, according to the UN Children‚Äôs Fund (UNICEF).

entry.title: UN rights chief underlines need for a permanent ceasefire and accountability in Gaza
entry.summary: Recovery in Gaza must also include accountability for violations, the UN High Commissioner for Human Rights said on Wednesday.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Guterres highlights ‚Äòmaximum impact‚Äô reform agenda
entry.summary: The Secretary-General on Wednesday outlined a set of proposals to strengthen the UN‚Äôs effectiveness and improve coordination across its three core pillars: peace and security, sustainable development, and human rights.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Humanitarian funding cuts pushing millions into hunger: WFP
entry.summary: Nearly 14 million people could face severe hunger by the end of the year, the World Food Programme (WFP) warned on Wednesday, as slashed humanitarian funding threatens six of its most critical operations.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Gaza peace plan ‚Äòat precarious moment‚Äô as killings continue on both sides
entry.summary: The UN relief chief on Wednesday urged Israel and Hamas to honour their agreement to return deceased hostages and allow aid at scale into Gaza, warning that it should not be used as ‚Äúa bargaining chip‚Äù amid reports of new civilian killings and extrajudicial executions.

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Record rise in carbon dioxide levels during 2024: UN weather agency
entry.summary: Atmospheric carbon dioxide levels rose by a record amount in 2024, reaching new highs and locking in further long-term warming and extreme weather, according to the World Meteorological Organization (WMO).

author.name: UN News - Global perspective Human stories

entry.title: Great art explained: The School of Athens by Raphael
entry.summary: A close look at ‚ÄòThe School of Athens‚Äô reveals how Raphael turned to the past to capture the progress of his times - by Aeon Video Watch on Aeon

entry.title: Why do we have bunions? Blame an evolutionary toe failure.
entry.summary:
Bunions have plagued human feet since ancient times. A brief glimpse at archaeology and history points to their presence, from prehistoric footprints in England to ancient Egyptian mummies with bony bumps.
A whopping 27 percent of burials in and around Cambridge, England, during the 14th and 15th centuries showed skeletal evidence of bunions, compared with just 6 percent in earlier centuries. The likely culprit? Researchers attribute the difference to the medieval emergence of ‚Äúpoulaine‚Äù shoes, long leather footwear with a pointed tip.
But why do we get them in the first place‚Äîand why haven‚Äôt we figured out how they‚Äôre caused or cured without surgery? Here‚Äôs how our feet developed one of their most common woes‚Äîand why they still perplex scientists.
Also known as hallux val‚Ä¶

entry.title: How to hack the Mediterranean diet to meet your own needs
entry.summary:
The Mediterranean diet is one of the healthiest on the planet, emphasizing lots of vegetables, fruits, nuts, legumes, healthy fats, and whole grains‚Äîplus moderate amounts of fish, seafood, poultry, and eggs. But experts say you can easily riff on these core principles for a more personalized approach that suits your health needs and taste preferences. Scientists are exploring how simple tweaks to this trusted diet can address specific health concerns, including hypertension, chronic pain, cardiovascular health, and more.
You‚Äôve undoubtedly heard that the Mediterranean diet is one of the healthiest on the planet‚Äîand that‚Äôs true, given its association with various health benefits and even greater longevity. These perks and the fact that it‚Äôs been so well studied are what make it so t‚Ä¶

entry.title: Inside the colossal quest for limitless energy
entry.summary:
Real stars, the ones in space, are simple beasts. Our sun formed some 4.6 billion years ago from a cloud consisting of essentially one ingredient: hydrogen, the most basic and abundant element in the universe. Gravity kneaded the cloud into a big, rotating ball and kept squeezing from there, density and warmth spiking, until its core reached about 27 million degrees Fahrenheit.
Hydrogen crumbles when collisions occur at this temperature and pressure, creating the soupy jumble of atomic parts known as plasma, the fourth state of matter after solid, liquid, and gas. Though rare on Earth outside of lightning bolts and neon signs, plasma accounts for over 99 percent of the solar system‚Äôs mass, most of it stored, highly agitated, in the sun. Throughout the sun‚Äôs soup, trillions of times ev‚Ä¶

entry.title: Most supplements can‚Äôt actually boost your mood‚Äîbut these might
entry.summary:
Once meant to bridge nutritional gaps, supplements have become a booming market for mental wellness.
With an estimated 5.7 percent of adults suffering from depression worldwide, more people are turning to over-the-counter supplements like vitamins, minerals, herbal extracts, amino acids, and probiotics in hopes of finding relief. For many, the appeal lies not just in accessibility, but in perception.
‚ÄúWith medications there is a lot of stigma around mental health, and people can be very scared about what that looks like,‚Äù says Nicholas Fabiano, a researcher in the Department of Psychiatry at the University of Ottawa. ‚ÄúWhich makes people want to try other things that are perceived to maybe be safer, or less intense, or maybe require a shorter duration of treatment.‚Äù
But do th‚Ä¶

entry.title: Discover the best of Lucerne beyond the city centre
entry.summary:
Since the 19th century, the German-speaking city of Lucerne has attracted royals, writers and musicians, inspiring the likes of Goethe, Queen Victoria and Wagner (the latter composed several major works while living in the region). But this culturally rich city is also the gateway to the Lake Lucerne region, a compact yet geographically diverse area where travellers can pack unique Swiss experiences into a few short days. With historic mountain railways and charming Alpine towns, not to mention the chance to relax in a lakeside spa, this underrated slice of Switzerland is not to be missed. Here are five experiences awaiting travellers who journey beyond Lucerne‚Äôs city centre.
A distinct feature of central Switzerland is its historic mountain railways, built in the 19th century to ma‚Ä¶

entry.title: Why this ghostly hyena image is the best wildlife photo of 2025
entry.summary:
It took ten years for Wim van den Heever to capture his perfect shot. After noticing paw prints and scat in an abandoned mining town along the coast of southern Namibia, he saw an opportunity to snap a picture of a brown hyena, the rarest hyena in the world. Amid fog drifting in from the Atlantic Ocean, he set up his camera trap and waited. And waited.
Van den Heever‚Äôs patience and perseverance rewarded him with a striking, ghostly portrait of a brown hyena ‚Äúin the most perfect frame imaginable,‚Äù gazing into the night beside the skeletal remains of a long-abandoned building. The photograph, ‚ÄòGhost Town Visitor‚Äô, earned him the prestigious title of 61st Wildlife Photographer of the Year, awarded today by London‚Äôs Natural History Museum.
The photograph is an ‚Äúeerie juxtaposition of‚Ä¶
